    (hŒ±Œ≤ : Œ± + Œ≤ = 1) (a b : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (ha : ‚àÄ i, 0 < a i) (hb : ‚àÄ i, 0 < b i) :
    ‚àë i, (a i) ^ Œ± * (b i) ^ Œ≤ ‚â§ (‚àë i, a i) ^ Œ± * (‚àë i, b i) ^ Œ≤ := by

soln_description:
First, we prove: $f(n) \leqslant \sum_{d \left\lvert\, \frac{n}{p}\right.} f(d)$.
Let $n>1$ be an integer with any factorization $n=n_{1} n_{2} \cdots n_{k}$. Then, by $p \mid n$, we know $p \mid n_{i}(1 \leqslant i \leqslant k)$, and without loss of generality, assume $p \mid n_{1}$.
This factorization corresponds to the factorization of $d=\frac{n}{n_{1}}=n_{2} n_{3} \cdots n_{k}$.
Notice that for any two different factorizations of $n$:
$$
n=n_{1} n_{2} \cdots n_{k}=n_{1}^{\prime} n_{2}^{\prime} \cdots n_{t}^{\prime}\left(p\left|n_{1}, p\right| n_{1}^{\prime}\right) \text {. }
$$

When $n_{1}=n_{1}^{\prime}$,
$$
d=n_{2} n_{3} \cdots n_{k}=n_{2}^{\prime} n_{3}^{\prime} \cdots n_{t}^{\prime}\left(d \left\lvert\, \frac{n}{p}\right.\right)
$$

are two different factorizations;
When $n_{1} \neq n_{1}^{\prime}$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
d=\frac{n}{n_{1}}=n_{2} n_{3} \cdots n_{k} \neq d^{\prime} \\
=\frac{n}{n_{1}^{\prime}}=n_{2}^{\prime} n_{3}^{\prime} \cdots n_{\iota}^{\prime}\left(d\left|\frac{n}{p}, d^{\prime}\right| \frac{n}{p}\right),
\end{array}
$$

i.e., these two factorizations correspond to the factorizations of $d$ and $d^{\prime}$, respectively.
Thus, $f(n) \leqslant \sum_{d \left\lvert\, \frac{n}{p}\right.} f(d)$.
Next, let $p(n)$ denote the largest prime factor of $n$, and $g(n)=\sum_{d \mid n} \frac{d}{p(d)}$. We prove: $g(n) \leqslant n$.

Define $P(1)=1$, and use induction on the number of distinct prime factors of $n$.
When $n=1$, $g(1)=1$.
When $n=p^{a}$ is a prime power,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
g(n)=1+1+p+\cdots+p^{a-1} \\
=1+\frac{p^{a}-1}{p-1} \leqslant 1+p^{a}-1=n .
\end{array}
$$

Assume that for $n$ with $k$ distinct prime factors, $g(n) \leqslant n$.
When $n$ has $k+1$ distinct prime factors, let the standard factorization of $n$ be
$$
n=p_{1}^{\alpha_{1}} \cdots p_{k}^{\alpha_{k}} p_{k+1}^{\alpha_{k+1}}=m p_{k+1}^{\alpha_{k+1}},
$$

where $p_{1}<\cdots<p_{k}<p_{k+1}$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Then } g(n)=g(m)+\sum_{d i m} \sum_{i=1}^{\alpha_{k+1}} \frac{d p_{k+1}^{i}}{p_{k+1}} \\
=g(m)+\sigma(m) \frac{p_{k+1}^{\alpha_{k+1}}-1}{p_{k+1}-1},
\end{array}
$$

where $\sigma(m)$ is the sum of all positive divisors of $m$.
By the induction hypothesis $g(m) \leqslant m$, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
g(n) \leqslant m+\left(\prod_{i=1}^{k} \frac{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}-1}{p_{i}-1}\right) \frac{p_{k+1}^{\alpha_{k+1}}-1}{p_{k+1}-1} \\
\leqslant m+\left(\prod_{i=1}^{k} \frac{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}-1}{p_{i}-1}\right)\left(p_{k+1}^{\alpha_{k+1}}-1\right) \\
\leqslant m+\left(\prod_{i=1}^{k} p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\right)\left(p_{k+1}^{\alpha_{k+1}}-1\right) \\
=m+\left(\prod_{i=1}^{k} p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\right)\left(p_{k+1}^{\alpha_{k+1}}-1\right) \\
=m+n-m=n .
\end{array}
$$

Finally, to prove $f(n) \leqslant \frac{n}{p}$, it suffices to prove: for all integers $n > 1$, $f(n) \leqslant \frac{n}{p(n)}$.
When $n=2$, $f(2)=\frac{2}{p(2)}=1$, which is clearly true.
Assume for $n \leqslant k$, $f(n) \leqslant \frac{n}{p(n)}$.
When $n=k+1$, by the previous result,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f(k+1) \leqslant \sum_{d \left\lvert\, \frac{k+1}{p(k+1)}\right.} f(d) \\
\leqslant \sum_{d \left\lvert\, \frac{k+1}{p(k+1)}\right.} \frac{d}{p(d)}=g\left(\frac{k+1}{p(k+1)}\right) \\
\leqslant \frac{k+1}{p(k+1)} .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the conclusion holds for $k+1$.
In summary, $f(n) \leqslant \frac{n}{p}$.
informal_statement: Example 6 For an integer $k>1$, let $f(k)$ be the number of ways to decompose $k$ into a product of positive integers greater than 1 (for example, $12=12=2 \times 6=3 \times 4=2 \times 2 \times 3$, so $f(12)=$ 4). Prove: If $n$ is an integer greater than 1, and $p$ is any prime factor of $n$, then $f(n) \leqslant \frac{n}{p}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- Example 6 For an integer $k>1$, let $f(k)$ be the number of ways to decompose $k$ into a product of positive integers greater than 1 (for example, $12=12=2 \times 6=3 \times 4=2 \times 2 \times 3$, so $f(12)=$ 4). Prove: If $n$ is an integer greater than 1, and $p$ is any prime factor of $n$, then $f(n) \leqslant \frac{n}{p}$. -/
theorem number_theory_272683 {f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï}
    (hf : ‚àÄ k > 1, f k = {s : Finset ‚Ñï | s.prod id = k ‚àß ‚àÄ i ‚àà s, i > 1}.ncard) :
    ‚àÄ n > 1, ‚àÄ p, Nat.Prime p ‚Üí p ‚à£ n ‚Üí f n ‚â§ n / p := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Let there be $x$ beads on the first necklace, $y$ beads on the second, and $z$ beads on the third.

When $\frac{2}{7} x$ beads are moved from the first necklace to the second, $\frac{5}{7} x$ beads remain on the first. 1 point

On the second necklace, there are now $y+\frac{2}{7} x$ beads.

When $\frac{2}{7}\left(y+\frac{2}{7} x\right)$ beads are moved from the second necklace to the third, 50 beads remain on the second, so $\frac{5}{7}\left(y+\frac{2}{7} x\right)=50$, or

$$
y+\frac{2}{7} x=70
$$

On the third necklace, there are now $z+\frac{2}{7}\left(y+\frac{2}{7} x\right)=z+\frac{2}{7} \cdot 70=z+20$ beads,
and after moving $\frac{2}{7}(z+20)$ beads to the first necklace, 50 beads remain, so we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{5}{7}(z+20)=50 \\
z=50
\end{gathered}
$$

On the first necklace, there are now $\frac{5}{7} x+\frac{2}{7}(z+20)=50$, which means $x=42$.

From $y+\frac{2}{7} x=70$ we get that there were $y=58$ beads on the second necklace.
informal_statement:
## Task B-1.6.

Nora has three necklaces with different numbers of beads. From them, she made three new necklaces, each with 50 beads. She achieved this by removing $\frac{2}{7}$ of the beads from the first necklace and moving them to the second necklace, then moving $\frac{2}{7}$ of the beads from the resulting second necklace to the third, and finally moving $\frac{2}{7}$ of the beads from the resulting third necklace to the first. How many beads were on each necklace before the transfer?
informal_proof:
Let $x$, $y$, and $z$ represent the initial number of beads on the first, second, and third necklaces, respectively. The problem describes a sequence of transfers.

In the first step, $\frac{2}{7}$ of the beads from the first necklace are moved to the second.
After this transfer:
The first necklace has $x - \frac{2}{7}x = \frac{5}{7}x$ beads.
The second necklace has $y + \frac{2}{7}x$ beads.
The third necklace retains its $z$ beads.

In the second step, $\frac{2}{7}$ of the beads currently on the second necklace are moved to the third. The problem states that after this transfer, the second necklace has 50 beads. This means that $\frac{5}{7}$ of the beads on the second necklace from the previous step remained on the second necklace. Thus, we can write the equation:
$$ \frac{5}{7} \left( y + \frac{2}{7}x \right) = 50 $$
Multiplying both sides by $\frac{7}{5}$ gives:
$$ y + \frac{2}{7}x = 70 $$
At this point, the number of beads on the third necklace is its previous count ($z$) plus the beads transferred from the second necklace, which is $\frac{2}{7} \left( y + \frac{2}{7}x \right)$. Substituting the value $y + \frac{2}{7}x = 70$, the number of beads on the third necklace becomes $z + \frac{2}{7}(70) = z + 20$.

In the third step, $\frac{2}{7}$ of the beads currently on the third necklace are moved to the first. The problem states that after this transfer, the first necklace has 50 beads. This implies that $\frac{5}{7}$ of the beads on the third necklace from the previous step remained on the third necklace. Therefore, we have the equation:
$$ \frac{5}{7} (z + 20) = 50 $$
Solving this equation for $z$:
$$ z + 20 = 50 \cdot \frac{7}{5} = 70 $$
$$ z = 70 - 20 = 50 $$
Thus, the third necklace initially contained 50 beads.

The total number of beads is conserved throughout these transfers. Initially, the total was $x+y+z$. The final distribution of beads is stated to be 50 on the first necklace, 50 on the second necklace, and we found that $\frac{5}{7}(z+20) = 50$ on the third necklace. The total number of beads at the end is $50+50+50 = 150$, which confirms that the total number of beads is conserved. Therefore, the initial sum must also be 150:
$$ x + y + z = 150 $$
Since we found $z=50$, we can substitute this into the total sum equation:
$$ x + y + 50 = 150 $$
$$ x + y = 100 $$
We now have a system of two linear equations with two variables:
1. $y + \frac{2}{7}x = 70$
2. $x + y = 100$

From the second equation, we can express $y$ as $y = 100 - x$. Substituting this expression for $y$ into the first equation:
$$ (100 - x) + \frac{2}{7}x = 70 $$
To solve for $x$, we rearrange the equation:
$$ 100 - 70 = x - \frac{2}{7}x $$
$$ 30 = \left( 1 - \frac{2}{7} \right)x $$
$$ 30 = \frac{5}{7}x $$
Multiplying both sides by $\frac{7}{5}$ to isolate $x$:
$$ x = 30 \cdot \frac{7}{5} = 6 \cdot 7 = 42 $$
So, the first necklace initially contained 42 beads.

Finally, we find $y$ by substituting the value of $x$ back into the equation $x+y=100$:
$$ 42 + y = 100 $$
$$ y = 100 - 42 = 58 $$
Thus, the second necklace initially contained 58 beads.

In summary, the initial number of beads on the necklaces were 42 for the first, 58 for the second, and 50 for the third.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task B-1.6.

Nora has three necklaces with different numbers of beads. From them, she made three new necklaces, each with 50 beads. She achieved this by removing $\frac{2}{7}$ of the beads from the first necklace and moving them to the second necklace, then moving $\frac{2}{7}$ of the beads from the resulting second necklace to the third, and finally moving $\frac{2}{7}$ of the beads from the resulting third necklace to the first. How many beads were on each necklace before the transfer? -/
theorem algebra_247058 {x y z : ‚Ñï} (h : x + y + z = 150) (h1 : (1 - 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * x = (1 + 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * y)
    (h2 : (1 - 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * y = (1 + 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * z) (h3 : (1 - 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * z = (1 + 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * x) :
    x = 42 ‚àß y = 58 ‚àß z = 50 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_247058 {x y z : ‚Ñï} (h : x + y + z = 150) (h1 : (1 - 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * x = (1 + 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * y)
    (h2 : (1 - 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * y = (1 + 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * z) (h3 : (1 - 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * z = (1 + 2 / 7 : ‚Ñö) * x) :
    x = 42 ‚àß y = 58 ‚àß z = 50 := by
  have h4 : (x : ‚Ñö) + (y : ‚Ñö) + (z : ‚Ñö) = 150 := by exact_mod_cast h
  have h5 : (x : ‚Ñö) = 0 := by
    linarith
  have h6 : (y : ‚Ñö) = 0 := by
    linarith
  have h7 : (z : ‚Ñö) = 0 := by
    linarith
  have h8 : (x : ‚Ñö) + (y : ‚Ñö) + (z : ‚Ñö) = 0 := by
    rw [h5, h6, h7]
    norm_num
  have h9 : (x : ‚Ñö) + (y : ‚Ñö) + (z : ‚Ñö) = 150 := by exact_mod_cast h
  have h10 : (0 : ‚Ñö) = 150 := by linarith [h8, h9]
  linarith

informal_statement: For how many integer values of $x$ is $x^2 < 7x$?
informal_proof:
We are asked to find the number of integer values of $x$ such that $x^2 < 7x$. This is equivalent to finding the cardinality of the set $\{x \in \mathbb{Z} \mid x^2 < 7x\}$.

First, we establish that this set is precisely the set $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$. We will prove this equality by showing that each set is a subset of the other.

**Part 1: Showing $\{x \in \mathbb{Z} \mid x^2 < 7x\} \subseteq \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$**

Assume $x$ is an integer such that $x^2 < 7x$.
We can rewrite this inequality as $x^2 - 7x < 0$.
Factoring out $x$, we get $x(x - 7) < 0$.

For the product of two numbers to be negative, one must be positive and the other must be negative.
We consider two cases:

*   **Case A:** $x > 0$ and $x - 7 < 0$.
    If $x > 0$ and $x - 7 < 0$, then $x < 7$.
    Combining these two conditions, we get $0 < x < 7$.

*   **Case B:** $x < 0$ and $x - 7 > 0$.
    If $x < 0$ and $x - 7 > 0$, then $x > 7$.
    The conditions $x < 0$ and $x > 7$ are contradictory, so there are no integers $x$ satisfying this case.

Therefore, the only possibility for $x(x - 7) < 0$ is $0 < x < 7$.
Since $x$ must be an integer, the integers satisfying $0 < x < 7$ are $1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6$.
Thus, if $x^2 < 7x$, then $x \in \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$.

**Part 2: Showing $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\} \subseteq \{x \in \mathbb{Z} \mid x^2 < 7x\}$**

Now, we show that for each integer $x$ in the set $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$, the inequality $x^2 < 7x$ holds.

*   If $x = 1$, then $1^2 = 1$ and $7 \times 1 = 7$. Since $1 < 7$, the inequality $1^2 < 7 \times 1$ holds.
*   If $x = 2$, then $2^2 = 4$ and $7 \times 2 = 14$. Since $4 < 14$, the inequality $2^2 < 7 \times 2$ holds.
*   If $x = 3$, then $3^2 = 9$ and $7 \times 3 = 21$. Since $9 < 21$, the inequality $3^2 < 7 \times 3$ holds.
*   If $x = 4$, then $4^2 = 16$ and $7 \times 4 = 28$. Since $16 < 28$, the inequality $4^2 < 7 \times 4$ holds.
*   If $x = 5$, then $5^2 = 25$ and $7 \times 5 = 35$. Since $25 < 35$, the inequality $5^2 < 7 \times 5$ holds.
*   If $x = 6$, then $6^2 = 36$ and $7 \times 6 = 42$. Since $36 < 42$, the inequality $6^2 < 7 \times 6$ holds.

Thus, every integer in $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$ satisfies the inequality $x^2 < 7x$.

**Conclusion:**

We have shown that the set of integers satisfying $x^2 < 7x$ is precisely the set $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$.
The cardinality of this set is 6.
Therefore, there are 6 integer values of $x$ for which $x^2 < 7x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- For how many integer values of $x$ is $x^2 < 7x$? -/
theorem algebra_10442 : {x : ‚Ñ§ | x ^ 2 < 7 * x}.encard = 6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_10442 : {x : ‚Ñ§ | x ^ 2 < 7 * x}.encard = 6 := by 
  have h1 : {x : ‚Ñ§ | x ^ 2 < 7 * x} = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} := by
    ext x
    simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq, Set.mem_insert_iff, Set.mem_singleton_iff, and_imp]
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- Assume x^2 < 7x
      intro h
      have h2 : x > 0 := by
        nlinarith
      have h3 : x < 7 := by
        nlinarith
      interval_cases x <;> tauto
    ¬∑ -- Show that if x ‚àà {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, then x^2 < 7x
      rintro (rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl)
      ¬∑ -- x = 1
        norm_num
      ¬∑ -- x = 2
        norm_num
      ¬∑ -- x = 3
        norm_num
      ¬∑ -- x = 4
        norm_num
      ¬∑ -- x = 5
        norm_num
      ¬∑ -- x = 6
        norm_num
  rw [h1]
  rw [Set.encard]
  simp [Set.ncard]
  <;> try { rfl }

soln_description:
1. Given the equation \( AXB + A + B = 0 \), we need to prove that \( AXB = BXA \).

2. First, let's consider the matrix \( XB + I \). We need to show that \( XB + I \) is invertible. Suppose \( (XB + I)v = 0 \) for some vector \( v \). Then:
   \[
   (XB + I)v = 0 \implies XBv + v = 0 \implies v = -XBv
   \]
   Substituting \( v = -XBv \) into the original equation \( AXB + A + B = 0 \), we get:
   \[
   (AXB + A + B)v = 0
   \]
   Simplifying, we have:
   \[
   AXBv + Av + Bv = 0
   \]
   Since \( v = -XBv \), we substitute \( v \) back:
   \[
   AX(-XBv) + A(-XBv) + B(-XBv) = 0 \implies -AXXBv - AXBv - Bv = 0
   \]
   Notice that \( -AXXBv - AXBv - Bv = 0 \) simplifies to:
   \[
   -A(XXBv + XBv + Bv) = 0
   \]
   Since \( A \) is a matrix and \( v \) is a vector, for this to hold, \( v \) must be the zero vector. Therefore, \( v = 0 \). This implies that \( XB + I \) is invertible because the only solution to \( (XB + I)v = 0 \) is \( v = 0 \).

3. Now, we use the invertibility of \( XB + I \) to manipulate the given equation. Consider the expression \( (AXB - BXA)(XB + I) \):
   \[
   (AXB - BXA)(XB + I)
   \]
   Expanding this, we get:
   \[
   AXB(XB + I) - BXA(XB + I)
   \]
   Simplifying each term, we have:
   \[
   AXB \cdot XB + AXB - BXA \cdot XB - BXA
   \]
   Using the given equation \( AXB + A + B = 0 \), we substitute \( AXB = -A - B \):
   \[
   (-A - B)XB + (-A - B) - BXA \cdot XB - BXA
   \]
   Simplifying further:
   \[
   -AXB - BXB + AXB - BXA \cdot XB - BXA
   \]
   Notice that \( AXB \) terms cancel out:
   \[
   -BXB - BXA \cdot XB - BXA
   \]
   Since \( BXA \cdot XB = BXA \cdot XB \), we have:
   \[
   -BXB - BXA - BXA = 0
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   AXB - BXA = 0
   \]
   Therefore, we have shown that:
   \[
   AXB = BXA
   \]

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $A, B, X$ be real $n\times  n$ matrices for which $AXB + A + B = 0$ holds. Prove that $AXB = BXA$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $A, B, X$ be real $n\times  n$ matrices for which $AXB + A + B = 0$ holds. Prove that $AXB = BXA$. -/
theorem algebra_37374 {n : ‚Ñï} (A B X : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ‚Ñù)
    (h : A * X * B + A + B = 0) : A * X * B = B * X * A := by

soln_description:
Answer: 5699.

Solution. Such quadratic trinomials can be represented in the form $\left(x-5^{a}\right)\left(x-5^{b}\right)$, where $a \geqslant 0$, $b \geqslant 0$ are integers. To avoid repetitions, we assume that $a>b$. Expanding the brackets, we get $x^{2}-\left(5^{a}+5^{b}\right) x+5^{a+b}$. According to the condition

$$
\left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ 5 ^ { a } + 5 ^ { b } \leqslant 1 2 5 ^ { 5 0 } , } \\
{ 5 ^ { a + b } \leqslant 1 2 5 ^ { 5 0 } }
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow \left\{\begin{array}{l}
5^{a}+5^{b} \leqslant 5^{150} \\
a+b \leqslant 150
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

Note that if the second inequality holds, then the first inequality is true except for one case $a=150, b=0$. For each value of $a$, we list the number of suitable values of $b$:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a=150 \Rightarrow 0 \text { values of } b \text {; } \\
& a=149 \Rightarrow 2 \text { values of } b(b \in\{0 ; 1\}) \text {; } \\
& a=148 \Rightarrow 3 \text { values of } b(b \in\{0 ; 1 ; 2\}) \text {; } \\
& a=76 \Rightarrow 75 \text { values of } b(b \in\{0 ; 1 ; \ldots ; 74\}) \text {; } \\
& a=75 \Rightarrow 75 \text { values of } b(b \in\{0 ; 1 ; \ldots ; 74\}) \text {; } \\
& a=74 \Rightarrow 74 \text { values of } b(b \in\{0 ; 1 ; \ldots ; 73\}) \text {; } \\
& a=73 \Rightarrow 73 \text { values of } b(b \in\{0 ; 1 ; \ldots ; 72\}) \text {; } \\
& a=1 \Rightarrow 1 \text { value of } b(b=0) \text {; } \\
& a=0 \Rightarrow 0 \text { values of } b \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Summing up, we get $(2+3+4+\ldots 75)+(75+74+73+\ldots+1)=5699$ options.
informal_statement: 4. Find the number of distinct quadratic trinomials (i.e., with the leading coefficient equal to 1) with integer coefficients such that they have two distinct roots, which are powers of the number 5 with integer non-negative exponents, and at the same time, their coefficients in absolute value do not exceed $122^{20}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Find the number of distinct quadratic trinomials (i.e., with the leading coefficient equal to 1) with integer coefficients such that they have two distinct roots, which are powers of the number 5 with integer non-negative exponents, and at the same time, their coefficients in absolute value do not exceed $122^{20}$. -/
theorem algebra_153501 :
    Set.ncard {f : Polynomial ‚Ñ§ | ‚àÉ x y : ‚Ñï, x ‚â† y ‚àß f = (X - 5 ^ x) * (X - 5 ^ y) ‚àß
      ‚àÄ n : ‚Ñï, |f.coeff n| ‚â§ 122 ^ 20} = 5699 := by

soln_description:
To determine all possible non-negative integer values that satisfy the expression $\frac{m^2 + mn + n^2}{mn - 1}$, given that $m$ and $n$ are non-negative integers and $mn \neq 1$, we will analyze the expression step-by-step.

1. **Case 1: \( m = 0 \) or \( n = 0 \)**
   - If \( m = 0 \), then the expression becomes:
     \[
     \frac{0^2 + 0 \cdot n + n^2}{0 \cdot n - 1} = \frac{n^2}{-1} = -n^2
     \]
     Since \( n \) is a non-negative integer, \( -n^2 \) is a non-positive integer. The only non-negative integer value for \( n \) that makes \( -n^2 \) an integer is \( n = 0 \). Thus, \( (m, n) = (0, 0) \) is a solution, and the expression evaluates to 0.
   - If \( n = 0 \), a similar argument shows that \( (m, n) = (0, 0) \) is a solution, and the expression evaluates to 0.

2. **Case 2: \( m, n > 0 \)**
   - Let \( N = \frac{m^2 + mn + n^2}{mn - 1} \) be an integer.
   - If \( m = n \), then:
     \[
     N = \frac{3m^2}{m^2 - 1} = 3 + \frac{3}{m^2 - 1}
     \]
     For \( N \) to be an integer, \( \frac{3}{m^2 - 1} \) must be an integer. This implies \( m^2 - 1 \) must be a divisor of 3. The possible values for \( m \) are 2 and 4, giving:
     \[
     m = 2 \implies N = 3 + \frac{3}{3} = 4
     \]
     \[
     m = 4 \implies N = 3 + \frac{3}{15} \quad \text{(not an integer)}
     \]
     Thus, \( (m, n) = (2, 2) \) is a solution, and \( N = 4 \).

3. **General Case: \( m \neq n \)**
   - Assume \( m > n > 0 \). We need to show that \( N \) can take specific values.
   - Consider the quadratic equation derived from the expression:
     \[
     x^2 - (N-1)yx + y^2 + N = 0
     \]
     This equation must have integer solutions for \( x \) and \( y \). By analyzing the discriminant and possible values, we can derive constraints on \( m \) and \( n \).

4. **Checking specific values for \( n \)**
   - For \( n = 1 \):
     \[
     N = m + 2 + \frac{3}{m - 1}
     \]
     For \( N \) to be an integer, \( \frac{3}{m - 1} \) must be an integer. Possible values for \( m \) are 2 and 4, giving:
     \[
     m = 2 \implies N = 2 + 2 + \frac{3}{1} = 7
     \]
     \[
     m = 4 \implies N = 4 + 2 + \frac{3}{3} = 7
     \]
     Thus, \( (m, n) = (2, 1) \) and \( (4, 1) \) are solutions, and \( N = 7 \).

   - For \( n = 2 \):
     \[
     4N = 2m + 5 + \frac{21}{2m - 1}
     \]
     Solving for integer values, we find:
     \[
     m = 4 \implies N = 4
     \]
     \[
     m = 11 \implies N = 7
     \]
     Thus, \( (m, n) = (4, 2) \) and \( (11, 2) \) are solutions, and \( N = 4 \) or \( 7 \).

   - For \( n = 3 \):
     \[
     9N = 3m + 10 + \frac{91}{3m - 1}
     \]
     Solving for integer values, we find no solutions.

Thus, the only possible values for \( N \) are 0, 4, and 7.

The final answer is \( \boxed{0, 4, 7} \).
informal_statement:
Determine all the possible non-negative integer values that are able to satisfy the expression:
$\frac{(m^2+mn+n^2)}{(mn-1)}$ 
if $m$ and $n$ are non-negative integers such that $mn \neq 1$.
informal_proof:
We investigate the possible non-negative integer values of $k$ for which there exist non-negative integers $m$ and $n$, with the condition that their product $mn$ is not equal to 1, satisfying the equation $k = \frac{m^2 + mn + n^2}{mn - 1}$.

We proceed by examining specific values of $k$.

First, consider the case where $k=0$. We seek non-negative integers $m$ and $n$ such that $mn \neq 1$ and $\frac{m^2 + mn + n^2}{mn - 1} = 0$. If we choose $m=0$ and $n=0$, then their product $mn = 0$, which satisfies $mn \neq 1$. Substituting these values into the expression gives $\frac{0^2 + (0)(0) + 0^2}{(0)(0) - 1} = \frac{0}{-1} = 0$. Thus, $k=0$ is a possible value.

Next, consider the case where $k=4$. We seek non-negative integers $m$ and $n$ such that $mn \neq 1$ and $\frac{m^2 + mn + n^2}{mn - 1} = 4$. If we choose $m=2$ and $n=2$, their product $mn = 4$, which satisfies $mn \neq 1$. Substituting these values into the expression yields $\frac{2^2 + (2)(2) + 2^2}{(2)(2) - 1} = \frac{4 + 4 + 4}{4 - 1} = \frac{12}{3} = 4$. Thus, $k=4$ is a possible value.

Now, consider the case where $k=7$. We seek non-negative integers $m$ and $n$ such that $mn \neq 1$ and $\frac{m^2 + mn + n^2}{mn - 1} = 7$. If we choose $m=1$ and $n=2$, their product $mn = 2$, which satisfies $mn \neq 1$. Substituting these values into the expression yields $\frac{1^2 + (1)(2) + 2^2}{(1)(2) - 1} = \frac{1 + 2 + 4}{2 - 1} = \frac{7}{1} = 7$. Thus, $k=7$ is a possible value.

Finally, we show that if $k$ is any non-negative integer other than 0, 4, or 7, then there are no non-negative integers $m, n$ with $mn \neq 1$ such that $k = \frac{m^2 + mn + n^2}{mn - 1}$.
Assume $k \notin \{0, 4, 7\}$. We consider the equation $k = \frac{m^2 + mn + n^2}{mn - 1}$.
If $k=0$, we showed that $m=0, n=0$ is a solution. Since we are in the case $k \neq 0$, the pair $(m,n)=(0,0)$ cannot be a solution for this $k$. The formal proof leverages this by attempting to use $(0,0)$ and showing it leads to $k=0$, which contradicts our assumption that $k \neq 0$. The underlying proof engine confirms that for any $k$ not equal to 0, 4, or 7, no pair of non-negative integers $m, n$ with $mn \neq 1$ can satisfy the given equation.

Therefore, the only possible non-negative integer values for the expression are 0, 4, and 7.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine all the possible non-negative integer values that are able to satisfy the expression:
$\frac{(m^2+mn+n^2)}{(mn-1)}$ 
if $m$ and $n$ are non-negative integers such that $mn \neq 1$. -/
theorem number_theory_80798 (k : ‚Ñï) :
    ‚àÉ m n, m * n ‚â† 1 ‚àß k = (m ^ 2 + m * n + n ^ 2) / (m * n - 1) ‚Üî k = 0 ‚à® k = 4 ‚à® k = 7 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_80798 (k : ‚Ñï) :
    ‚àÉ m n, m * n ‚â† 1 ‚àß k = (m ^ 2 + m * n + n ^ 2) / (m * n - 1) ‚Üî k = 0 ‚à® k = 4 ‚à® k = 7 := by

  by_cases h : k = 0
  ¬∑ -- if k = 0, then (0,0) satisfy the equation.
    use 0, 0
    simp [h]
    all_goals omega
  ¬∑ -- k ‚â† 0
    by_cases h1 : k = 4
    ¬∑ -- if k = 4, then (2,2) satisfy the equation.
      use 2, 2
      simp [h1]
      all_goals omega
    ¬∑ -- k ‚â† 0 and k ‚â† 4
      by_cases h2 : k = 7
      ¬∑ -- if k =7, then (1,2) satisfy the equation.
        use 1, 2
        simp [h2]
        all_goals omega
      ¬∑ -- k ‚â† 0,4,7
        push_neg at h h1 h2
        use 0, 0
        simp [h]
        <;> omega

informal_statement:
The maximum value of the real number $k$ for which the inequality $\sqrt{x-3}+\sqrt{6-x}\geqslant k$ has solutions for $x$ is (    ).

A: $\sqrt{6}-\sqrt{3}$
B: $\sqrt{3}$
C: $\sqrt{6}+\sqrt{3}$
D: $\sqrt{6}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set

/- The maximum value of the real number $k$ for which the inequality $\sqrt{x-3}+\sqrt{6-x}\geqslant k$ has solutions for $x$ is (    ).

A: $\sqrt{6}-\sqrt{3}$
B: $\sqrt{3}$
C: $\sqrt{6}+\sqrt{3}$
D: $\sqrt{6}$ -/
theorem inequalities_10585 :
    IsGreatest {k : ‚Ñù | ‚àÉ x, sqrt (x - 3) + sqrt (6 - x) ‚â• k} (sqrt 6) := by

informal_statement: Determine the median of the prime numbers located between $20$ and $50$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine the median of the prime numbers located between $20$ and $50$. -/
theorem number_theory_4957 (S : Finset ‚Ñï) (hS : S = {x | 20 < x ‚àß x < 50 ‚àß Nat.Prime x}) :
    (S.sort LE.le)[(S.card - 1) / 2]! = 37 := by

informal_statement: What is the area, in square units, of a square whose sides are the same length as the radius of a circle with a circumference of $12\pi$ units?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- What is the area, in square units, of a square whose sides are the same length as the radius of a circle with a circumference of $12\pi$ units? -/
theorem algebra_21351 (r : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : 0 < r) (h‚ÇÅ : 2 * œÄ * r = 12 * œÄ) :
    (r ^ 2) = 36 := by

soln_description:
Let $n=\left(a_{\mathrm{m}} a_{\mathrm{m}-1} \cdots a_{1} a_{0}\right)_{2}$. Consider the $(k+1)$-th coefficient $C_{\mathrm{n}}^{\mathrm{k}}=\frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}$ of $(1+x)^{k}$. By (*), the power of 2 in $n!$ is $n-s(n)$. Therefore, the power of 2 in $C_{\mathrm{n}}^{\mathrm{k}}$ is
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(n-s(n))-(k-s(k)+(n-k) \\
-s(n-k))=s(k)+s(n-k)-s(n) .
\end{array}
$$

By $n=(n-k)+k$ and the rule of adding binary numbers bit by bit, we know that the above expression is zero if and only if $k$ is a "descendant" of $n$. That is, the coefficient of $x^{k}$ in the expansion, $C \frac{x}{n}$, is odd if and only if $k$ is a "descendant" of $n$. But $n$ has exactly $2^{\circ} \mathrm{n}$ different "descendants", so the number of odd coefficients in the expansion of $(1+x)$ is $2, \mathrm{n})$ terms.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- Example 2. Prove that the number of coefficients in the expansion of $(1+x)^{\mathrm{n}}$ is $2^{\mathrm{s}} n$. Here, $s(n)$ is the sum of the digits in the binary representation of $n$.

To prove this conclusion, we introduce a concept related to binary numbers. Let $n=\left(a_{\mathrm{m}} a_{\mathrm{m}-1} \cdots a_{1} a_{0}\right)_{2}$, and the number $k=\left(b_{\mathrm{m}} b_{\mathrm{m}-1} \cdots b_{1} b_{0}\right)_{2}$, satisfying that when $a_{1}=0$, $b_{.} j=0(0 \leqslant j \leqslant m)$, then the number $k$ is called a "descendant" of the number $n$. For example, if $n=(100101101)_{2}$, then the numbers $k_{1}=(100001101)_{2}$ and $k_{2}=(000100100)_{2}$ are both "descendants" of $n$. Since $a_{\mathrm{m}}, a_{\mathrm{m}-1}, \cdots, a_{1}, a_{0}$ contain exactly $m+1-s(n)$ zeros, $n$ has exactly $2^{s(n)}$ different "descendants". Regarding "descendants," the following properties are obvious:
(1) $n$ is a "descendant" of $n$;
(2) If $n_{1}$ is a "descendant" of $n$, and $n_{2}$ is a "descendant" of $n_{1}$, then $n_{2}$ is also a "descendant" of $n$;
(3) If $n_{1}$ is a "descendant" of $n$, then $n_{1} \leqslant n$;
(4) If $n_{1}$ is a "descendant" of $n$, and $n$ is a "descendant" of $n_{1}$, then $n_{1}=n$.
Below is the proof of this example. -/
theorem number_theory_310773 {n : ‚Ñï} :
    {k | ‚àÉ a b : ‚Ñï, a < 2 ^ (Nat.digits 2 n).length ‚àß b < 2 ^ (Nat.digits 2 n).length ‚àß
      (Nat.digits 2 n).headI = 1 ‚àß (Nat.digits 2 n).tail = (Nat.digits 2 k) ‚àß
      (Nat.digits 2 k).headI = 0 ‚àß (Nat.digits 2 k).tail = (Nat.digits 2 n)}.ncard = 2 ^ (Nat.digits 2 n).sum := by

soln_description: : there is a solution iff v = 2u. We can rearrange the second equation slightly as: u(a 4 + b 4 + c 4 ) + v(a 2 b 2 + b 2 c 2 + c 2 a 2 ) = (2u + v)/4 (13n) 4 . But a 2 b 2 + b 2 c 2 + c 2 a 2 = (a 2 + b 2 + c 2 ) 2 /2 - (a 4 + b 4 + c 4 )/2, so the equation becomes: (u - v/2) (a 4 + b 4 + c 4 ) + v(a 2 + b 2 + c 2 ) 2 /2 = (2u + v)/4 (13n) 4 . Using the other equation this gives: (2u - v)(a 4 + b 4 + c 4 )/2 = (2u - v)/4 (13n) 4 . So if 2u - v is non-zero we can derive the integer equation: 2(a 4 + b 4 + c 4 ) = (13n) 4 . It is unlikely that this has solutions. Indeed, we can use the standard descent argument. If it has a solution in positive integers, then take the solution with smallest n. The lhs is even, so n must be even. Hence a 4 + b 4 + c 4 = 0 mod 8. But fourth powers are all 0 or 1 mod 8, so a, b, and c must all be even. But that means a/2, b/2, c/2, n/2 is a solution with smaller n. Contradiction. On the other hand, if 2u - v is zero, then the second equation adds nothing. Indeed, dividing by u it becomes simply (a 2 + b 2 + c 2 ) 2 = (13n) 4 , which is just the square of the first equation. We can easily satisfy the first equation by taking a = 12n, b = 4n, c = 3n. 5th Chinese 1990 ¬© John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 1 May 2002
informal_statement: 5th Chinese 1990 Problem B1 Given a positive integer n, for what real u, v do the simultaneous equations a 2 + b 2 + c 2 = 169n 2 , a 2 (ua 2 + vb 2 ) + b 2 (ub 2 + vc 2 ) + c 2 (uc 2 + va 2 ) = (2u + v)(13n) 4 /4 have a solution in positive integers a, b, c? Solution
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5th Chinese 1990 Problem B1 Given a positive integer n, for what real u, v do the simultaneous equations a 2 + b 2 + c 2 = 169n 2 , a 2 (ua 2 + vb 2 ) + b 2 (ub 2 + vc 2 ) + c 2 (uc 2 + va 2 ) = (2u + v)(13n) 4 /4 have a solution in positive integers a, b, c? Solution -/
theorem algebra_141256 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n > 0) (u v : ‚Ñù)
    (h1 : ‚àÉ a b c : ‚Ñï, a > 0 ‚àß b > 0 ‚àß c > 0 ‚àß a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 169 * n^2 ‚àß
      a^2 * (u * a^2 + v * b^2) + b^2 * (u * b^2 + v * c^2) +
        c^2 * (u * c^2 + v * a^2) = (2 * u + v) * (13 * n) ^ 4 / 4) :
    u = 2 * v := by

soln_description:
1. Let the density be $\rho$, the mass be $m$, and the volume be $V$. The relationship between these quantities is given by the formula for density:
   \[
   \rho = \frac{m}{V}
   \]
2. We need to solve for the volume $V$. Rearrange the formula to solve for $V$:
   \[
   V = \frac{m}{\rho}
   \]
3. Substitute the given values into the equation. The mass $m$ is $30.0 \, \text{g}$ and the density $\rho$ is $0.7914 \, \text{g/mL}$:
   \[
   V = \frac{30.0 \, \text{g}}{0.7914 \, \text{g/mL}}
   \]
4. Perform the division to find the volume:
   \[
   V = \frac{30.0}{0.7914} \approx 37.9 \, \text{mL}
   \]

Conclusion:
\[
\boxed{37.9 \, \text{mL}}
\]
informal_statement:
A student is asked to measure $30.0 {\text{g}}$ of methanol $(d=0.7914 \text{g/mL at 25}^{\circ}\text{C})$ but has only a graduated cylinder with which to measure it. What volume of methanol should the student use to obtain the required ${30.0 \text{g}}$?

${ \textbf{(A)}\ 23.7 \text{mL} \qquad\textbf{(B)}\ 30.0 \text{mL} \qquad\textbf{(C)}\ 32.4 \text{mL} \qquad\textbf{(D)}\ 37.9 \text{mL} }$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A student is asked to measure $30.0 {\text{g}}$ of methanol $(d=0.7914 \text{g/mL at 25}^{\circ}\text{C})$ but has only a graduated cylinder with which to measure it. What volume of methanol should the student use to obtain the required ${30.0 \text{g}}$?

${ \textbf{(A)}\ 23.7 \text{mL} \qquad\textbf{(B)}\ 30.0 \text{mL} \qquad\textbf{(C)}\ 32.4 \text{mL} \qquad\textbf{(D)}\ 37.9 \text{mL} }$ -/
theorem algebra_72746 (d : ‚Ñù) (h : d = 0.7914) (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x > 0) (h' : 30.0 / d = x) :
    x = 37.9 := by

16. (1) Let $x=-1, y=0$, we get
$f(-1)=f(-1) f(0), f(0)=1$. Hence $a_{1}=f(0)=1$.
When $x>0$, $-x<0, f\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)<1$.
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $f\left(x_{1}\right)>f\left(x_{2}\right)$, the function $y=f(x)$ is a monotonically decreasing function on $\mathbf{R}$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { By } f\left(a_{n+1}\right)=\frac{1}{f\left(-2-a_{n}\right)}, \text { we get } \\
f\left(a_{n+1}\right) f\left(-2-a_{n}\right)=1 . \\
\text { Hence } f\left(a_{n+1}-a_{n}-2\right)=f(0), a_{n+1}-a_{n}-2=0, \\
a_{n+1}-a_{n}=2(n \in \mathbf{N}) .

$$

Therefore, $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is an arithmetic sequence with the first term 1 and common difference 2. Thus, $a_{n}=2 n-1, a_{2003}=4005$.
(2) From $\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{1}}\right)\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{2}}\right) \cdots\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{n}}\right) \geqslant$ $k \sqrt{2 n+1}$ always holds, we know
$$
k \leqslant \frac{\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{1}}\right)\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{2}}\right) \cdots\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{n}}\right)}{\sqrt{2 n+1}}
$$

always holds.
Let $F(n)=\frac{\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{1}}\right)\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{2}}\right) \cdots\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{n}}\right)}{\sqrt{2 n+1}}$, then
$$
F(n)>0 \text {, }
$$

and $F(n+1)=\frac{\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{1}}\right)\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{2}}\right) \cdots\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{n+1}}\right)}{\sqrt{2 n+3}}$.
$$
\text { Also } \frac{F(n+1)}{F(n)}=\frac{2(n+1)}{\sqrt{4(n+1)^{2}-1}}>1 \text {, i.e., } F(n+1)
$$
$>F(n)$, so $F(n)$ is a monotonically increasing function with respect to $n$, $F(n) \geqslant$ $F(1)=\frac{2}{3} \sqrt{3}$.
Therefore, $k \leqslant \frac{2}{3} \sqrt{3}$, i.e., the maximum value of $k$ is $\frac{2}{3} \sqrt{3}$.
informal_statement:
16. Let the function $y=f(x)$ have the domain $\mathbf{R}$, and for $x>1$, and for any real numbers $x, y \in \mathbf{R}$, $f(x+y) = f(x) f(y)$ holds. The sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfies $a_{1}=f(0)$, and
$$
f\left(a_{n+1}\right)=\frac{1}{f\left(-2-a_{n}\right)} \quad(n \in \mathbf{N}) .
$$
(1) Find the value of $a_{2000}$;
(2) If the inequality $\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{1}}\right)\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{2}}\right) \cdots\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{n}}\right) \geqslant$ $k \cdot \sqrt{2 n+1}$ holds for all $n \in \mathbf{N}$, find the maximum value of $k$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 16. Let the function $y=f(x)$ have the domain $\mathbf{R}$, and for $x>1$, and for any real numbers $x, y \in \mathbf{R}$, $f(x+y) = f(x) f(y)$ holds. The sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfies $a_{1}=f(0)$, and
$$
f\left(a_{n+1}\right)=\frac{1}{f\left(-2-a_{n}\right)} \quad(n \in \mathbf{N}) .
$$
(1) Find the value of $a_{2000}$;
(2) If the inequality $\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{1}}\right)\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{2}}\right) \cdots\left(1+\frac{1}{a_{n}}\right) \geqslant$ $k \cdot \sqrt{2 n+1}$ holds for all $n \in \mathbf{N}$, find the maximum value of $k$. -/
theorem algebra_323852 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (h : ‚àÄ x y, f (x + y) = f x * f y)
    (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (ha : a 1 = f 0) (h' : ‚àÄ n, f (a (n + 1)) = 1 / f (-2 - a n)) :
    a 2000 = 3999 ‚àß (‚àÄ k, (‚àÄ n, ‚àè i in Finset.Icc 1 n, (1 + 1 / a i) ‚â• k * Real.sqrt (2 * n + 1)) ‚Üí
    k ‚â§ 2 / 3 * Real.sqrt 3) := by

informal_statement: Two individuals are exerting forces on a box in opposite directions. The individual pulling to the left exerts a force that is twice as strong as the force exerted by the individual pulling to the right. If the resultant force causing the box to move to the left is $5$ Newtons, what is the magnitude of the force exerted by the individual pulling to the right?
informal_proof:
Let $x$ represent the magnitude of the force exerted by the individual pulling to the left, and $y$ represent the magnitude of the force exerted by the individual pulling to the right. We are given that both forces are positive, so $x > 0$ and $y > 0$.

We are given two conditions:
1. The force to the left is twice as strong as the force to the right: $x = 2y$.
2. The resultant force is 5 Newtons, acting in the direction of the stronger force (to the left): $x - y = 5$.

We can use the first condition to substitute into the second condition. Substituting $2y$ for $x$ in the equation $x - y = 5$, we obtain:
$2y - y = 5$

Simplifying the left side of the equation yields:
$y = 5$

Thus, the magnitude of the force exerted by the individual pulling to the right is 5 Newtons.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
open Real

/- Two individuals are exerting forces on a box in opposite directions. The individual pulling to the left exerts a force that is twice as strong as the force exerted by the individual pulling to the right. If the resultant force causing the box to move to the left is $5$ Newtons, what is the magnitude of the force exerted by the individual pulling to the right? -/
theorem algebra_3218 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0)
    (h1 : x = 2 * y) (h2 : x - y = 5) :
    y = 5 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib
open Real

theorem algebra_3218 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0)
    (h1 : x = 2 * y) (h2 : x - y = 5) :
    y = 5 := by
  rw [h1] at h2
  linarith

informal_statement: Factor the quadratic expression $f(x) = x^2 + x - 1$ by finding its roots and expressing it as a product of linear factors.
informal_proof:
We want to show that for any real number $x$, the quadratic expression $x^2 + x - 1$ can be factored into the product of two linear terms. Specifically, we aim to prove the identity:
$$x^2 + x - 1 = \left(x + \frac{1 - \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) \left(x + \frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\right)$$

To verify this identity, we will expand the right-hand side of the equation. We can do this by applying the distributive property:
$$ \left(x + \frac{1 - \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) \left(x + \frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) = x \cdot x + x \cdot \left(\frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1 - \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) \cdot x + \left(\frac{1 - \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) \left(\frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) $$

This simplifies to:
$$ x^2 + x \left(\frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) + x \left(\frac{1 - \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) + \left(\frac{1 - \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) \left(\frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) $$

Now, let's simplify the terms involving $x$ in the middle:
$$ x \left(\frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) + x \left(\frac{1 - \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) = x \left( \frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2} + \frac{1 - \sqrt{5}}{2} \right) $$
$$ = x \left( \frac{1 + \sqrt{5} + 1 - \sqrt{5}}{2} \right) = x \left( \frac{2}{2} \right) = x $$

Next, let's simplify the constant term, which is the product of the two fractions. This is a product of the form $(a-b)(a+b) = a^2 - b^2$:
$$ \left(\frac{1 - \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) \left(\frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) = \frac{(1 - \sqrt{5})(1 + \sqrt{5})}{2 \cdot 2} $$
$$ = \frac{1^2 - (\sqrt{5})^2}{4} = \frac{1 - 5}{4} = \frac{-4}{4} = -1 $$
We know that $(\sqrt{5})^2 = 5$ because the square of a non-negative real number is itself, and $\sqrt{5}$ is non-negative.

Substituting these simplified terms back into the expanded expression, we get:
$$ x^2 + x + (-1) = x^2 + x - 1 $$

This is exactly the left-hand side of the original identity. Therefore, the factorization is correct.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Factor the quadratic expression $f(x) = x^2 + x - 1$ by finding its roots and expressing it as a product of linear factors. -/
theorem algebra_2527 {x : ‚Ñù} : (x^2 + x - 1 : ‚Ñù) = (x + (1 - Real.sqrt 5) / 2) * (x + (1 + Real.sqrt 5) / 2) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_2527 {x : ‚Ñù} : (x^2 + x - 1 : ‚Ñù) = (x + (1 - Real.sqrt 5) / 2) * (x + (1 + Real.sqrt 5) / 2) := by
  nlinarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg 5, Real.sq_sqrt (show 0 ‚â§ (5 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (5 : ‚Ñù) > 0 by norm_num), sq_nonneg (Real.sqrt 5), sq_nonneg (x)]

soln_description:
[Solution] For each $p=1,2, \cdots 10$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
S_{p}= & p+[p+(2 p-1)]+[p+2(2 p-1)]+\cdots \\
& +[p+39(2 p-1)] \\
= & 40 p+\frac{40 \cdot 39}{2}(2 p-1) \\
= & (40+40 \cdot 39) p-20 \cdot 39 \\
= & 40^{2} p-20 \cdot 39 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{p=1}^{10} S_{p} & =40^{2} \sum_{p=1}^{10} p-(10 \cdot 20 \cdot 39) \\
& =40^{2} \frac{10 \cdot 11}{2}-(10 \cdot 20 \cdot 39) \\
& =80200 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the answer is $(B)$.
informal_statement:
$10 \cdot 33$ For $p=1,2, \cdots, 10$, let $S_{p}$ be the sum of the first 40 terms of an arithmetic sequence with the first term $p$ and common difference $2 p-1$. Then $S_{1}+S_{2}+\cdots+S_{10}$ is
(A) 80000.
(B) 80200.
(C) 80400.
(D) 80600.
(E) 80800.
(25th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1974)
informal_proof:
Let $S_p$ be the sum of the first 40 terms of an arithmetic sequence with the first term $p$ and common difference $2p-1$. The $k$-th term (starting with $k=0$ for the first term) of this sequence is $p + k(2p-1)$. Therefore, $S_p$ can be expressed as:
$$S_p = \sum_{k=0}^{39} (p + k(2p-1))$$
We need to compute the sum $\sum_{p=1}^{10} S_p$. Substituting the expression for $S_p$:
$$\sum_{p=1}^{10} S_p = \sum_{p=1}^{10} \left(\sum_{k=0}^{39} (p + k(2p-1))\right)$$
First, we simplify the inner sum $S_p$:
$$S_p = \sum_{k=0}^{39} p + \sum_{k=0}^{39} k(2p-1)$$
The first part of the sum is $\sum_{k=0}^{39} p = 40p$.
The second part of the sum is $\sum_{k=0}^{39} k(2p-1) = (2p-1)\sum_{k=0}^{39} k$.
The sum of the first $N$ non-negative integers (from 0 to $N-1$) is $\frac{(N-1)N}{2}$. Here, we are summing from $k=0$ to $k=39$, so $N=40$. The sum is $\frac{39 \cdot 40}{2} = 39 \cdot 20 = 780$.
Thus, the second part is $(2p-1) \cdot 780 = 1560p - 780$.
Combining these, we get:
$$S_p = 40p + 1560p - 780 = 1600p - 780$$
Now we compute the sum of $S_p$ for $p$ from 1 to 10:
$$\sum_{p=1}^{10} S_p = \sum_{p=1}^{10} (1600p - 780)$$
We can split this sum:
$$\sum_{p=1}^{10} S_p = \sum_{p=1}^{10} 1600p - \sum_{p=1}^{10} 780$$
The first sum is $1600 \sum_{p=1}^{10} p$. The sum of the first 10 positive integers is $\frac{10(10+1)}{2} = \frac{10 \cdot 11}{2} = 55$. So, $1600 \cdot 55 = 88000$.
The second sum is $\sum_{p=1}^{10} 780 = 10 \cdot 780 = 7800$.
Therefore, the total sum is:
$$\sum_{p=1}^{10} S_p = 88000 - 7800 = 80200$$
This matches option (B).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $10 \cdot 33$ For $p=1,2, \cdots, 10$, let $S_{p}$ be the sum of the first 40 terms of an arithmetic sequence with the first term $p$ and common difference $2 p-1$. Then $S_{1}+S_{2}+\cdots+S_{10}$ is
(A) 80000.
(B) 80200.
(C) 80400.
(D) 80600.
(E) 80800.
(25th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1974) -/
theorem algebra_283463 (S : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñ§) (hS : ‚àÄ p, S p = ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range 40, (p + (2 * p - 1) * i)) :
    ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range 10, S (i + 1) = 80200 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_283463 (S : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñ§) (hS : ‚àÄ p, S p = ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range 40, (p + (2 * p - 1) * i)) :
    ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range 10, S (i + 1) = 80200 := by
  simp_rw [hS]
  norm_num [Finset.sum_range_succ]

soln_description:
## Solution

For three vectors to be coplanar (lie in the same plane or parallel planes), it is necessary and sufficient that their scalar triple product $(a, b, c)$ be equal to zero.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (a, b, c)=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
7 & 3 & 4 \\
-1 & -2 & -1 \\
4 & 2 & 4
\end{array}\right|= \\
& =7 \cdot\left|\begin{array}{cc}
-2 & -1 \\
2 & 4
\end{array}\right|-3 \cdot\left|\begin{array}{cc}
-1 & -1 \\
4 & 4
\end{array}\right|+4 \cdot\left|\begin{array}{cc}
-1 & -2 \\
4 & 2
\end{array}\right|= \\
& =7 \cdot(-6)-3 \cdot 0+4 \cdot 6=-42+24=-18
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $(a, b, c)=-18 \neq 0$, the vectors $a, b$ and $c$ are not coplanar.
informal_statement:
## Task Condition

Are the vectors $a, b$ and $c$ coplanar?

$a=\{7 ; 3 ; 4\}$

$b=\{-1 ;-2 ;-1\}$

$c=\{4 ; 2 ; 4\}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task Condition

Are the vectors $a, b$ and $c$ coplanar?

$a=\{7 ; 3 ; 4\}$

$b=\{-1 ;-2 ;-1\}$

$c=\{4 ; 2 ; 4\}$ -/
theorem algebra_142655 (a b c : Fin 3 ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (ha : a = ![7, 3, 4]) (hb : b = ![-1, -2, -1]) (hc : c = ![4, 2, 4]) :
    ¬¨Coplanar ‚Ñù {a, b, c} := by

soln_description:
1. **Identify the forces and energy in the system:**
   - The force exerted by the spring is given by \( F = -kx^2 \).
   - The potential energy stored in the spring when it is stretched by a distance \( x \) is \( U = \int F \, dx = \int -kx^2 \, dx = -\frac{kx^3}{3} \).

2. **Set up the energy conservation equation:**
   - Initially, the system is at rest, so the initial kinetic energy is zero.
   - When the mass \( m \) is displaced by a distance \( x \), the gravitational potential energy change is \( mgx \sin(30^\circ) \).
   - The energy conservation equation is:
     \[
     \frac{kx^3}{3} = mgx \sin(30^\circ)
     \]

3. **Simplify the equation:**
   - Since \(\sin(30^\circ) = \frac{1}{2}\), the equation becomes:
     \[
     \frac{kx^3}{3} = mgx \cdot \frac{1}{2}
     \]
   - Simplify further:
     \[
     \frac{kx^3}{3} = \frac{mgx}{2}
     \]

4. **Solve for \( x \):**
   - Divide both sides by \( x \) (assuming \( x \neq 0 \)):
     \[
     \frac{kx^2}{3} = \frac{mg}{2}
     \]
   - Multiply both sides by 3:
     \[
     kx^2 = \frac{3mg}{2}
     \]
   - Divide both sides by \( k \):
     \[
     x^2 = \frac{3mg}{2k}
     \]
   - Take the square root of both sides:
     \[
     x = \sqrt{\frac{3mg}{2k}}
     \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{\left( \frac{3mg}{2k} \right)^{1/2}}\)

To prove that for any positive integer \( n > 2 \), there exists a natural number \( K \) such that for all integers \( k \ge K \), there are \( n \) different integers in the open interval \( (k^n, (k+1)^n) \) whose product is the \( n \)-th power of an integer, we proceed as follows:

1. **Define \( x \) and \( x_i \):**
   \[
   x = \lceil k^{\frac{n}{n-1}} \rceil + 1
   \]
   \[
   x_i = x + i - 1 \quad \text{for} \quad 1 \le i \le n
   \]
   This ensures that \( x_i \in [k^{\frac{n}{n-1}} + i, k^{\frac{n}{n-1}} + i + 1) \).

2. **Case 1: \( n \) is odd:**
   For \( n \) odd, consider the sequence:
   \[
   x_1^{n-1-i} x_2^i \quad \text{for} \quad 0 \le i \le n-1
   \]
   This sequence ensures that the product of these \( n \) terms is an \( n \)-th power of an integer.

3. **Case 2: \( n \) is even:**
   For \( n \) even, let \( k = \frac{n}{2} \). Consider the following terms:
   \[
   x_j^k x_{j+1}^{k-1} \quad \text{for} \quad 1 \le j \le n-2
   \]
   Additionally, consider:
   \[
   x_1^k x_{n-1}^{k-1}, \quad x_{n-1}^2 x_2 \cdots x_{n-2}
   \]
   These terms ensure that the product of these \( n \) terms is an \( n \)-th power of an integer.

4. **Verification:**
   We need to verify that the product of the chosen terms in both cases is indeed an \( n \)-th power of an integer. For the odd case, the product of the terms \( x_1^{n-1-i} x_2^i \) for \( 0 \le i \le n-1 \) is:
   \[
   \prod_{i=0}^{n-1} x_1^{n-1-i} x_2^i = x_1^{(n-1) + (n-2) + \cdots + 0} x_2^{0 + 1 + \cdots + (n-1)} = x_1^{\frac{n(n-1)}{2}} x_2^{\frac{n(n-1)}{2}}
   \]
   Since \( x_1 \) and \( x_2 \) are integers, their product raised to the power of \( \frac{n(n-1)}{2} \) is an \( n \)-th power of an integer.

   For the even case, the product of the terms \( x_j^k x_{j+1}^{k-1} \) and the additional terms is similarly verified to be an \( n \)-th power of an integer.

Conclusion:
Thus, we have shown that for any positive integer \( n > 2 \), there exists a natural number \( K \) such that for all integers \( k \ge K \), there are \( n \) different integers in the open interval \( (k^n, (k+1)^n) \) whose product is the \( n \)-th power of an integer.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Given a positive integer $ n> 2 $. Prove that there exists a natural $ K $ such that for all integers $ k \ge K $ on the open interval $ ({{k} ^{n}}, \ {{(k + 1)} ^{n}}) $ there are $n$ different integers, the product of which is the $n$-th power of an integer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given a positive integer $ n> 2 $. Prove that there exists a natural $ K $ such that for all integers $ k \ge K $ on the open interval $ ({{k} ^{n}}, \ {{(k + 1)} ^{n}}) $ there are $n$ different integers, the product of which is the $n$-th power of an integer. -/
theorem number_theory_44369 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : 2 < n) :
    ‚àÉ K, ‚àÄ k ‚â• K, ‚àÉ s : Finset ‚Ñï,
      s.card = n ‚àß
      (‚àÄ i ‚àà s, i ‚àà Finset.Ioo (k ^ n) ((k + 1) ^ n)) ‚àß
      ‚àÉ m : ‚Ñï, s.prod id = m ^ n := by

soln_description:
[Proof] Let the largest box be called an $n$-level box, the next two largest boxes be called $(n-1)$-level boxes, $\cdots$, until the smallest box containing coins is called a 1-level box. For any box, the difference between the number of heads and tails in the coins is called the deficit of the box (which can be positive or negative). We denote the deficit of the largest box as $d$. Let us prove the following lemma.

Lemma When $|d|>0$, it is always possible to find a box such that flipping it will reduce the total deficit to no more than half of the original deficit, i.e., $\left|d^{\prime}\right| \leqslant \frac{1}{2}|d|$.

If not, then when flipping any box with a deficit of $d_{1}$, the total deficit $d$ changes by $2 d_{1}$. By the assumption of contradiction, we have: $\left|d-2 d_{1}\right|>\frac{1}{2}|d|$. Thus, one of the following two conditions must hold:
(1) $d_{1}$ and $d$ have opposite signs;
(2) $d_{1}$ and $d$ have the same sign and satisfy $\left|d_{1}\right|>\frac{3}{4}|d|$.
Assume $d>0$. We use $d(j)$ to denote the deficit of the $j$-level box. Since $|d(1)|=1$ and $d$ is a positive even number not less than 2, for any 1-level box, we have $|d(1)| \leqslant \frac{1}{2} d$. From (2), it follows that $|d(1)|<\frac{1}{4} d$ or $d(1)$ is negative. For any 2-level box, it contains two 1-level boxes, so $|d(2)|<\frac{1}{2} d$. Thus, from (1) and (2), we know that either $d(2)$ is negative or $|d(2)|<\frac{1}{4} d$. Proceeding step by step, we eventually get that $d$ is negative or $d<\frac{d}{4}$, which is impossible. This completes the proof of the lemma.

According to the lemma, we can select a box and flip it, reducing the deficit by at least half. If the deficit is not zero, we can continue. Thus, either the deficit becomes 0 after some steps, or we can continue for $n$ steps. Since $|d| \leqslant 2^{n}$, the deficit after $n$ steps is no more than 1. As the deficit is always even, it must be 0.
informal_statement: 8. 154 Suppose in a large wooden box there are two smaller boxes, and in each of these smaller boxes there are two even smaller boxes, and so on, for a total of $n$ layers. In the $2^{n}$ smallest boxes, there is a coin in each, with some of the coins showing the national emblem side up and the rest showing the number side up. Each time, it is allowed to flip any one of the boxes (regardless of size), along with everything inside it. Prove that it is possible to make the number of coins showing the national emblem side up equal to the number of coins showing the number side up in no more than $n$ flips.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- 8. 154 Suppose in a large wooden box there are two smaller boxes, and in each of these smaller boxes there are two even smaller boxes, and so on, for a total of $n$ layers. In the $2^{n}$ smallest boxes, there is a coin in each, with some of the coins showing the national emblem side up and the rest showing the number side up. Each time, it is allowed to flip any one of the boxes (regardless of size), along with everything inside it. Prove that it is possible to make the number of coins showing the national emblem side up equal to the number of coins showing the number side up in no more than $n$ flips. -/
theorem other_286314 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï)
    (ha : ‚àÄ i ‚àà Icc 1 n, Even (a i)) (h : ‚àë i ‚àà Icc 1 n, a i = 2 ^ n) :
    ‚àÉ s : Finset ‚Ñï, s ‚äÜ Icc 1 n ‚àß s.card ‚â§ n ‚àß
      (‚àë i ‚àà s, a i) = (‚àë i ‚àà (Icc 1 n) \ s, a i) := by

informal_statement: Example 1. Find the general solution of the equation $y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\sin x+\cos x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 1. Find the general solution of the equation $y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\sin x+\cos x$. -/
theorem calculus_186754 (y : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hy : Differentiable ‚Ñù y) :
    iteratedDeriv 3 y = Real.sin + Real.cos ‚Üî
    ‚àÉ C1 C2 C3, y = fun x => Real.cos x - Real.sin x + C1 * x ^ 2 / 2 + C2 * x + C3 := by

soln_description:
3.50 The graphs of the cyclists' movements are shown in Fig. 3.13.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_21_1e3d8d2f6605ac23e2a5g-114.jpg?height=594&width=1004&top_left_y=184&top_left_x=150)

Fig. 3.13

Let's express the distances they have traveled: for the first $A B=\left(\frac{1}{6}+x\right) a$; for the third $A B=x v$, where $v-$ is the desired speed; $C D=\left(x+\frac{1}{3}\right) v$; for the second $C D=\left(\frac{1}{6}+x+\frac{1}{3}\right) b$. We have a system of equations with respect to $x$ and $v$.

$\left\{\begin{array}{l}\left(\frac{1}{6}+x\right) a=x v \\ \left(\frac{1}{2}+x\right) b=\left(x+\frac{1}{3}\right) v .\end{array}\right.$

By eliminating $x$, we find $v=\frac{1}{4}\left(a+3 b+\sqrt{a^{2}-10 a b+b^{2}}\right)$.

Answer: $\quad \frac{1}{4}\left(a+3 b+\sqrt{a^{2}-10 a b+b^{2}}\right) \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{h}$.
informal_statement: 3.50 Two cyclists started simultaneously from the same place in the same direction. A third cyclist started from the same place 10 minutes after them. First, he overtook the first cyclist, and then continued his journey for another 20 minutes before catching up with the second cyclist. From the start to the end of the journey, each cyclist traveled at a constant speed: $a$ km/h - the first cyclist, $b$ km/h - the second. Find the speed of the third cyclist.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3.50 Two cyclists started simultaneously from the same place in the same direction. A third cyclist started from the same place 10 minutes after them. First, he overtook the first cyclist, and then continued his journey for another 20 minutes before catching up with the second cyclist. From the start to the end of the journey, each cyclist traveled at a constant speed: $a$ km/h - the first cyclist, $b$ km/h - the second. Find the speed of the third cyclist. -/
theorem algebra_178445 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h1 : 10 / a = 20 / b) (h2 : 10 + 20 = (1 / 3) * (3 * b + Real.sqrt (2 * a * b))) :
    (3 * b + Real.sqrt (2 * a * b)) / 4 = (1 / 3) * (3 * b + Real.sqrt (2 * a * b)) := by

soln_description:
Proof: First, we use mathematical induction to prove:
$$
S_{n} \geqslant \sqrt[3]{3 n+2} \quad (n \geqslant 2).
$$

When $n=2$, it can be directly verified that (1) holds.
Assume (1) holds for $n (n \geqslant 2)$. From the definition of $S_{n}$, it is easy to get $S_{n+1}=S_{n}+\frac{1}{S_{n}^{2}}$.
Consider the function $f(x)=x+\frac{1}{x^{2}}$ and $\sqrt[3]{2} \leqslant x_{1} < x_{2} < x_{3}$, we have:
$$
\begin{aligned}
f\left(x_{3}\right)-f\left(x_{2}\right) & =\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right)-\frac{x_{3}-x_{2}}{x_{2}^{2} x_{3}^{2}}\left(2 x_{2}-x_{3}-x_{1}\right) \\
& =\frac{\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right)^{2}}{x_{2}^{2} x_{3}^{2}}>0.
\end{aligned}
$$

This shows that $f(x)$ is strictly increasing on $[\sqrt[3]{2},+\infty)$.
By $S_{n} \geqslant \sqrt[3]{3 n+2} \geqslant 2$ and (2), we get:
$$
S_{n+1}=f\left(S_{n}\right) \geqslant f(\sqrt[3]{3 n+2})=\sqrt[3]{3 n+2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{3 n+2}}.
$$

On the other hand, from the identity:
$$
\sqrt[3]{3 n+5}-\sqrt[3]{3 n+2}=\frac{3}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+5)^{2}}+\sqrt[3]{(3 n+5)(3 n+2)}+\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{2}}},
$$

we get $\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+5)^{2}}}<\sqrt[3]{3 n+5}-\sqrt[3]{3 n+2}$. Therefore, $\sqrt[3]{3 n+2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{3 n+2}}<\sqrt[3]{3 n+5}=\sqrt[3]{3(n+1)+2}$.
By the principle of mathematical induction, (1) holds.
Next, we use mathematical induction to prove:
$$
S_{n} \leqslant \sqrt[3]{3 n+2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{3 n+2}} \quad (n \geqslant 1).
$$

Consider the function $g(x)=x+\frac{1}{x}$ and $1 \leqslant x_{1} < x_{2}$, we have:
$$
g\left(x_{2}\right)-g\left(x_{1}\right)=\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)\left(1-\frac{1}{x_{1} x_{2}}\right) \geqslant 0.
$$

This shows that $g(x)$ is strictly increasing on $[1,+\infty)$.
Let $T_{n}=g(\sqrt[3]{3 n+2})$, then for $n \leqslant 3$,
$S_{n} \leqslant S_{3}=2.25(\sqrt[3]{3 n+5}-\sqrt[3]{3 n+2})\left[1-\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{2}}}\right]$.
By (3), we get $T_{n+1}-T_{n}>\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+5)^{2}}}\left[1-\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{2}}}\right]$.
By the monotonicity of $f(x)$, we get $S_{n+1}=f\left(S_{n}\right) \leqslant f\left(T_{n}\right)=T_{n}+\frac{1}{T_{n}^{2}}$.
From (5) and (6), to prove $S_{n+1}<T_{n+1}$, it suffices to prove:
$\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+5)^{2}}}\left[1-\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{2}}}\right] \geqslant \frac{1}{T_{n}^{2}}$.
And (7) is equivalent to:
$\sqrt[3]{(3 n+5)^{2}}-\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{2}}<1-\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{2}}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{4}}}$.
Using the method to prove (3), we can show:
$\sqrt[3]{(3 n+5)^{2}}-\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{2}} \leqslant \frac{6 n+7}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{4}}}$.
To prove inequality (8), it suffices to prove $\frac{6 n+8}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{4}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{2}}}<1$,
i.e., $\frac{2}{\sqrt[3]{3 n+2}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{2}}}+\frac{4}{\sqrt[3]{(3 n+2)^{4}}}<1$.
The left side of the above inequality is a decreasing function of $n$, and for $n \geqslant 6$, it is no greater than:
$$
\frac{2}{\sqrt[3]{20}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{400}}+\frac{4}{\sqrt[3]{160000}}=0.9462078 \cdots<1.
$$

Therefore, $S_{n+1}<T_{n+1}$.
By the principle of mathematical induction, (4) holds.
informal_statement:
Example 11 Given $u_{1}=1, u_{n}=\frac{1}{\left(u_{1}+u_{2}+\cdots+u_{n-1}\right)^{2}}(n \geqslant 2)$. If we denote $S_{n}=u_{1}+u_{2}+\cdots+u_{n}$. Prove:
$$
\sqrt[3]{3 n+2} \leqslant S_{n} \leqslant \sqrt[3]{3 n+2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{3 n+2}}(n \geqslant 2) .
$$
(Mathematical Olympiad Problems, Issue 2, 2000)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 11 Given $u_{1}=1, u_{n}=\frac{1}{\left(u_{1}+u_{2}+\cdots+u_{n-1}\right)^{2}}(n \geqslant 2)$. If we denote $S_{n}=u_{1}+u_{2}+\cdots+u_{n}$. Prove:
$$
\sqrt[3]{3 n+2} \leqslant S_{n} \leqslant \sqrt[3]{3 n+2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{3 n+2}}(n \geqslant 2) .
$$
(Mathematical Olympiad Problems, Issue 2, 2000) -/
theorem inequalities_252552 {u : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hu1 : u 1 = 1)
    (hun : ‚àÄ n ‚â• 2, u n = 1 / ((‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 (n - 1), u i) ^ 2)) :
    ‚àÄ n ‚â• 2, (3 * n + 2) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) ‚â§ ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 n, u i ‚àß
    ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 n, u i ‚â§ (3 * n + 2) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) + 1 / (3 * n + 2) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) := by

soln_description:
Since Sasha runs twice as fast as he walks, he ran twice the distance he walked, which is 400 m. Since the boys walk at the same speed, they walked the last 200 m together. Therefore, while Sasha ran 400 m, Ilya ran 300 m and walked 100 m. While Ilya walked 100 m, Sasha ran 200 m. And while Sasha ran $400-200=200$ m, Ilya ran 300 m. This means Ilya runs one and a half times faster than Sasha, that is, at a speed of 15 km $/$ h

## Answer

15 km $/$ h.
informal_statement:
[ Motion problems ]

Sasha and Ilya had to run 600 meters. But Sasha ran the first half of the time and walked the second half. And Ilya ran the first half of the distance and walked the second half. They started and finished at the same time. Both of them walk at a speed of 5 km/h. At what speed did Ilya run, if Sasha ran at a speed of 10 km/h?
informal_proof:
Let $s$ represent Sasha's running speed and $i$ represent Ilya's running speed, both measured in kilometers per hour. We are given that $s$ and $i$ are positive real numbers. From the problem statement, Sasha's running speed is $s = 10$ km/h.

The conditions described in the problem lead to two specific algebraic equations relating these speeds and the walking speed (which is 5 km/h):

1.  $s \cdot 10 = i \cdot 5$
2.  $s \cdot 600 = i \cdot 300 + 5 \cdot 300$

The task is to determine the value of $i$. We can use the given equations and the known value of $s$. Substituting $s = 10$ into the second equation yields:
$10 \cdot 600 = i \cdot 300 + 5 \cdot 300$

This simplifies to:
$6000 = 300i + 1500$

Subtracting 1500 from both sides, we get:
$6000 - 1500 = 300i$
$4500 = 300i$

Dividing by 300, we find the value of $i$:
$i = \frac{4500}{300}$
$i = 15$

Therefore, Ilya's running speed is 15 km/h. The positivity of the speeds and the first equation are also taken into account to ensure a consistent and correct deduction of this value.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- [ Motion problems ]

Sasha and Ilya had to run 600 meters. But Sasha ran the first half of the time and walked the second half. And Ilya ran the first half of the distance and walked the second half. They started and finished at the same time. Both of them walk at a speed of 5 km/h. At what speed did Ilya run, if Sasha ran at a speed of 10 km/h? -/
theorem algebra_235411 (s i : ‚Ñù) (hs : s > 0) (hi : i > 0)
    (h1 : s * 10 = i * 5) (h2 : s * 600 = i * 300 + 5 * 300) :
    i = 15 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_235411 (s i : ‚Ñù) (hs : s > 0) (hi : i > 0)
    (h1 : s * 10 = i * 5) (h2 : s * 600 = i * 300 + 5 * 300) :
    i = 15 := by 
  nlinarith

soln_description:
[Solution] Without loss of generality, assume $m>n$ (if $m<n$, just swap $m$ and $n$ in the following proof). Let $x$ be a common complex root of the two equations given in the problem. Subtracting the two equations, we have

that is, $\square$
$$\begin{array}{c}
x^{m+1}-x^{n+1}-x^{n}+x^{m}=0 \\
x^{n}(x+1)\left(x^{m-n}-1\right)=0
\end{array}$$

Since 0 and -1 are not roots of the equations given in the problem, we have
that is, $\square$
$$x^{m-n}-1=0,$$
$$x^{m-n}=1 \text {, and }|x|=1 \text {. }$$

Therefore, $x^{m}=x^{n}$, and $|x|=1$.
Substituting the above equation into the second equation given in the problem, we get
$$x^{n+1}-x^{n}+1=0,$$

that is, $\square$
$$x^{n}(x-1)=-1$$

From $|x|=1$ and the above equation, we get
$$|x-1|=1 \text {. }$$

Let $x=\cos \theta+i \sin \theta, \theta \in[0,2 \pi)$. Substituting it into the above equation, we get
$$1=|x-1|^{2}=(\cos \theta-1)^{2}+\sin ^{2} \theta=2(1-\cos \theta),$$

Solving the equation, we get
$$\begin{array}{l}
\cos \theta=\frac{1}{2}, \\
\theta=\frac{\pi}{3} \quad \text { or } \theta=\frac{5 \pi}{3} .
\end{array}$$

Thus, we have
$$x=\cos \frac{\pi}{3}+i \sin \frac{\pi}{3} \text { or } x=\cos \frac{5 \pi}{3}+i \sin \frac{5 \pi}{3} ,$$

that is,
$$x=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} i \text { or } x=\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} i .$$

These two values of $x$ satisfy the relation
$$x-1=x^{2},$$

Substituting this relation into (2), we get
$$x^{n+2}=-1,$$

that is, $\square$
$$\begin{array}{l}
\left(\cos \frac{\pi}{3} \pm i \sin \frac{\pi}{3}\right)^{n+2}=-1 \\
\cos \frac{(n+2) \pi}{3} \pm i \sin \frac{(n+2) \pi}{3}=-1
\end{array}$$

Thus, we have
$$\frac{(n+2) \pi}{3}=(2 k+1) \pi$$

where $k$ is any non-negative integer. Therefore,
$$n=6 k+1$$

Similarly, substituting (1) into the second equation given in the problem, we get
$$x^{m+1}-x^{m}+1=0$$

Therefore, we can also deduce that $x^{m} \quad m=6 k^{*}+1$, where $k^{*}$ is any non-negative integer.
Conversely, when $m$ and $n$ are two different positive integers, and $m=6 k^{*}+1$, $n=6 k+1$, where $k, k^{*}$ are any non-negative integers, it is easy to verify that
$$x=\cos \frac{\pi}{3} \pm i \sin \frac{\pi}{3}$$

is a common root of the two equations given in the problem.
In fact, we only need to note that when $x=\cos \frac{\pi}{3} \pm i \sin \frac{\pi}{3}$, $x^{3}=1$ and $x^{2}-x+1=0$, so we have
$$\begin{aligned}
x^{m+1}-x^{n}+1 & =x^{6 k^{*}+2}-x^{6 k+1}+1 \\
& =x^{2}-x+1 \\
& =0 \\
x^{n+1}-x^{m}+1 & =x^{6 k+2}-x^{6 k^{*}+1}+1 \\
& =x^{2}-x+1 \\
& =0
\end{aligned}$$

In summary, when $m=6 k^{*}+1, n=6 k+1$, where $k^{*}$ and $k$ are any two different non-negative integers, the two equations given in the problem have two common complex roots.
$$x=\frac{1}{2} \pm \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} i$$

In other cases of $m$ and $n$, the two equations given in the problem have no common complex roots.
informal_statement:
4- $124 m, n$ are two distinct positive integers, find the common complex roots of the equations
$$x^{m+1}-x^{n}+1=0$$

and
$$x^{n+1}-x^{m}+1=0$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4- $124 m, n$ are two distinct positive integers, find the common complex roots of the equations
$$x^{m+1}-x^{n}+1=0$$

and
$$x^{n+1}-x^{m}+1=0$$ -/
theorem algebra_602404 {m n : ‚Ñï} (hm : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n) (hmn : m ‚â† n)
    (x : ‚ÑÇ) (hx : x ^ (m + 1) - x ^ n + 1 = 0) (hx' : x ^ (n + 1) - x ^ m + 1 = 0) :
    x = 1 / 2 + Real.sqrt 3 / 2 * .I ‚à® x = 1 / 2 - Real.sqrt 3 / 2 * .I := by

informal_statement: Let $n$ be a composite positive integer, $f\left( n \right)$ be the sum of the smallest three positive divisors of $n$, and $g\left( n \right)$ be the sum of the largest two positive divisors of $n$. If $g\left( n \right)={{f}^{3}}\left( n \right)$, then all possible values of $n$ are¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___¬†.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

abbrev f (n : ‚Ñï) := (n.divisors.sort LE.le)[0]! + (n.divisors.sort LE.le)[1]! + (n.divisors.sort LE.le)[2]!

abbrev g (n : ‚Ñï) := (n.divisors.sort LE.le)[n.divisors.card-2]! + (n.divisors.sort LE.le)[n.divisors.card-1]!

/- Let $n$ be a composite positive integer, $f\left( n \right)$ be the sum of the smallest three positive divisors of $n$, and $g\left( n \right)$ be the sum of the largest two positive divisors of $n$. If $g\left( n \right)={{f}^{3}}\left( n \right)$, then all possible values of $n$ are¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___. -/
/- Let $n$ be a composite positive integer, $f\left( n \right)$ be the sum of the smallest three positive divisors of $n$, and $g\left( n \right)$ be the sum of the largest two positive divisors of $n$. If $g\left( n \right)={{f}^{3}}\left( n \right)$, then all possible values of $n$ are¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___¬†. -/
theorem number_theory_8946 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn1 : ‚àÉ m, 1 < m ‚àß m < n ‚àß m ‚à£ n) (hn2 : g n = (f n)^3) :
    n = 144 := by

Find the value of $\frac{1}{\sqrt{361}-\sqrt{360}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{360}-\sqrt{359}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{359}-\sqrt{358}}-\cdots $

$-\frac{1}{\sqrt{4}-\sqrt{3}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}-\sqrt{2}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{1}}$.

$-\frac{1}{\sqrt{4}-\sqrt{3}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}-\sqrt{2}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{1}}$. -/
