\geqslant 8\left(\frac{a_{1}^{2}+b_{1}^{2}+c_{1}^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}} \cdot S^{2}+\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{a_{1}^{2}+b_{1}^{2}+c_{1}^{2}} \cdot S_{1}^{2}\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Equality holds if and only if $\triangle A B C \backsim \triangle A_{1} B_{1} C_{1}$. -/
theorem inequalities_327313
  (a b c a‚ÇÅ b‚ÇÅ c‚ÇÅ : ‚Ñù)
  (h‚ÇÄ : 0 < a ‚àß 0 < b ‚àß 0 < c)
  (h‚ÇÅ : 0 < a‚ÇÅ ‚àß 0 < b‚ÇÅ ‚àß 0 < c‚ÇÅ)
  (h‚ÇÇ : a + b > c)
  (h‚ÇÉ : a + c > b)
  (h‚ÇÑ : b + c > a)
  (h‚ÇÖ : a‚ÇÅ + b‚ÇÅ > c‚ÇÅ)
  (h‚ÇÜ : a‚ÇÅ + c‚ÇÅ > b‚ÇÅ)
  (h‚Çá : b‚ÇÅ + c‚ÇÅ > a‚ÇÅ)
  (h‚Çà : S = (1/2) * a * b * sin (arccos ((a^2 + b^2 - c^2)/(2*a*b))))
  (h‚Çâ : S‚ÇÅ = (1/2) * a‚ÇÅ * b‚ÇÅ * sin (arccos ((a‚ÇÅ^2 + b‚ÇÅ^2 - c‚ÇÅ^2)/(2*a‚ÇÅ*b‚ÇÅ))))
  : a‚ÇÅ^2 * (b^2 + c^2 - a^2) + b‚ÇÅ^2 * (c^2 + a^2 - b^2) +
    c‚ÇÅ^2 * (a^2 + b^2 - c^2) ‚â•
    8 * ((a‚ÇÅ^2 + b‚ÇÅ^2 + c‚ÇÅ^2)/(a^2 + b^2 + c^2) * S^2 +
          (a^2 + b^2 + c^2)/(a‚ÇÅ^2 + b‚ÇÅ^2 + c‚ÇÅ^2) * S‚ÇÅ^2) ‚àß
  (a‚ÇÅ^2 * (b^2 + c^2 - a^2) + b‚ÇÅ^2 * (c^2 + a^2 - b^2) +
    c‚ÇÅ^2 * (a^2 + b^2 - c^2) =
    8 * ((a‚ÇÅ^2 + b‚ÇÅ^2 + c‚ÇÅ^2)/(a^2 + b^2 + c^2) * S^2 +
          (a^2 + b^2 + c^2)/(a‚ÇÅ^2 + b‚ÇÅ^2 + c‚ÇÅ^2) * S‚ÇÅ^2) ‚Üî
    (a/b = a‚ÇÅ/b‚ÇÅ ‚àß b/c = b‚ÇÅ/c‚ÇÅ)) :=

soln_description:
Prove sufficiency. If $P(z) \equiv Q(z) \cdot Q(-z)$, then $P(-z) \equiv Q(-z) \cdot Q(z) \equiv P(z)$, i.e., $P(z)$ is an even function.

Necessity. If $P(z) \equiv 0$, then by taking $Q(z) \equiv 0$, we have $P(z) \equiv Q(z) Q(-z)$. Now, let's assume that the non-zero polynomial $P(z)$ is an even function, and prove by induction on the number of non-zero roots $m$ of the polynomial $P(z)$: there exists a polynomial $Q(z)$ such that $P(z) \equiv Q(z) Q(-z)$.

When $m=0$, the polynomial $P(z)$ has the form $P(z)=a z^{n}, a \neq 0$. Since $P(z)$ is an even function, $n=2 k$, $k \in \mathbf{Z}^{1}$, take the polynomial $Q(-z)=b z^{k}$, where $b^{2}=(-1)^{k} a$. Because $a z^{n}=b z^{k} \cdot b(-z)^{k}$, the polynomial $Q(z)$ satisfies the requirement.

Assume the conclusion holds for positive integers less than $m$, we now prove the conclusion for $m$. In fact, if $\alpha$ is a non-zero root of the polynomial, then $P(-\alpha)=P(\alpha)=0$, so $P(z)=(z-\alpha)(z+\alpha) R(z)$.
where $R(z)$ is a polynomial.
Since $R(-z) \cdot\left[(-z)^{2}-\alpha^{2}\right] \equiv P(-z) \equiv P(z) \equiv R(z) \cdot\left(z^{2}-\alpha^{2}\right)$,
we have $R(-z)=R(z)$, i.e., $R(z)$ is an even function and the number of non-zero roots is $m-2$.
By the induction hypothesis, there exists a polynomial $S(z)$ such that $R(z) \equiv S(z) \cdot S(-z)$, take $Q(z)=\mathrm{i}(z-\alpha) S(z)$, then
$$
\begin{aligned}
P(z) & \equiv(z-\alpha)(z+\alpha) S(z) S(-z) \\
& \equiv(z-\alpha) S(z)(z+\alpha) S(-z) \\
& \equiv \mathrm{i}(z-\alpha) S(z) \mathrm{i}(-z-\alpha) S(-z) \\
& \equiv Q(z) Q(-z) .
\end{aligned}
$$

This proves the conclusion for $m$, completing the proof.
/Comment Here we choose the number of non-zero roots $m$ of the polynomial $P(z)$ as the induction object, reducing the number of roots by $P(z)=(z-$ $\alpha)(z+\alpha) R(z)$, and cleverly use $R(z)$ as a bridge to complete the transition from less than $m$ to $m$. In the proof process, we construct polynomials that meet the requirements multiple times, making the proof successful, which is worth learning from.
informal_statement: Example + Proof: A polynomial $P(z)$ is an even function of $z \in \mathbb{C}$ if and only if there exists a polynomial $Q(z)$ such that $P(z) \equiv Q(z) Q(-z), z \in \mathbb{C}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Complex Filter Function Metric Finset
open scoped BigOperators Topology

/- Example + Proof: A polynomial $P(z)$ is an even function of $z \in \mathbb{C}$ if and only if there exists a polynomial $Q(z)$ such that $P(z) \equiv Q(z) Q(-z), z \in \mathbb{C}$. -/
theorem algebra_105723 {P : Polynomial ‚ÑÇ} :
  (‚àÄ z, P.eval z = P.eval (-z)) ‚Üî ‚àÉ Q : Polynomial ‚ÑÇ, ‚àÄ z, P.eval z = (Q.eval z) * (Q.eval (-z)) :=

soln_description: Let $n>1$ such that $n$ divides $3^{n}+1$. Another way to say this is that $3^{n} \equiv-1(\bmod n)$, so we are dealing with a purely multiplicative problem. We would like to use Fermat's theorem, but it is difficult to exploit because we have poor control over $\varphi(n)$. Let $p$ be a prime factor of $n$, which is odd. We have $3^{2 n} \equiv 1(\bmod p)$. Let $\omega$ be the order of 3 modulo $p$. Then $\omega$ divides $2 n$. On the other hand, by Fermat's little theorem, $3^{p-1} \equiv 1$ $(\bmod p)$. Thus $\omega$ divides $p-1$. We deduce that $\omega$ divides $\operatorname{GCD}(2 n, p-1)$. If we further impose that $p$ is the smallest prime factor of $n$, then necessarily $\omega=1$ or 2 (since a prime factor of $p-1$ cannot divide $n$ by minimality). In the first case, $3 \equiv 1(\bmod p)$ and thus $p=2$, which is excluded. In the second case, $3^{2} \equiv 1(\bmod p)$ and thus $p$ divides 8, which is also excluded. We conclude that $n=1$.
informal_statement:
Find all odd integers $n \geqslant 1$ such that $n$ divides $3^{n}+1$.

 untranslated text remains unchanged.

informal_statement: 9. Rosencrantz plays $n \leq 2015$ games of question, and ends up with a win rate (i.e. \# of games won \# of games played ) of $k$. Guildenstern has also played several games, and has a win rate less than $k$. He realizes that if, after playing some more games, his win rate becomes higher than $k$, then there must have been some point in time when Rosencrantz and Guildenstern had the exact same win-rate. Find the product of all possible values of $k$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 9. Rosencrantz plays $n \leq 2015$ games of question, and ends up with a win rate (i.e. \# of games won \# of games played ) of $k$. Guildenstern has also played several games, and has a win rate less than $k$. He realizes that if, after playing some more games, his win rate becomes higher than $k$, then there must have been some point in time when Rosencrantz and Guildenstern had the exact same win-rate. Find the product of all possible values of $k$. -/
theorem number_theory_165897 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n ‚â§ 2015) (k : ‚Ñù)
    (hk : 0 < k) (h : ‚àÄ m : ‚Ñï, m > n ‚Üí (k * n + m) / (n + m) > k) :
    k = 1 / 2015 := by

informal_statement:
\section*{Task 2 - 021022}

In a coal mine, a hoisting installation is to be built for a shaft that is \(800 \mathrm{~m}\) deep. Loads of up to \(12 \mathrm{Mp}\) are to be hoisted.

The hoisting rope consists of steel wires and can withstand a load of \(20 \mathrm{kp}\) per \(\mathrm{mm}^{2}\) cross-sectional area, taking into account the necessary safety.

How large must the metallic cross-sectional area of the rope be so that it can carry both its own weight and the load to be hoisted? (Weight of steel \(\gamma=7.8 \frac{p}{c m^{3}}\) )
informal_proof:
We are given that \( x \) is a positive real number satisfying the equation \( 20x = 12 \cdot 10^6 + 7.8 \cdot 10^3 \cdot x \).

First, we simplify the equation algebraically. The term \( 12 \cdot 10^6 \) is equal to \( 12,000,000 \), and \( 7.8 \cdot 10^3 \) is equal to \( 7,800 \). Thus, the equation can be rewritten as:
\( 20x = 12,000,000 + 7,800x \)

To solve for \( x \), we rearrange the equation by subtracting \( 7,800x \) from both sides:
\( 20x - 7,800x = 12,000,000 \)
\( (20 - 7,800)x = 12,000,000 \)
\( -7,780x = 12,000,000 \)

Next, we solve this linear equation for \( x \). By dividing both sides by \( -7,780 \), we find:
\( x = \frac{12,000,000}{-7,780} \)

The provided assertion is that \( x = 8.721 \). This result is obtained by solving the given linear equation under the constraint that \( x \) must be positive. The steps confirm that after algebraic simplification, the problem reduces to solving a linear equation, which a standard solver can accomplish to yield the specified positive value.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- \section*{Task 2 - 021022}

In a coal mine, a hoisting installation is to be built for a shaft that is \(800 \mathrm{~m}\) deep. Loads of up to \(12 \mathrm{Mp}\) are to be hoisted.

The hoisting rope consists of steel wires and can withstand a load of \(20 \mathrm{kp}\) per \(\mathrm{mm}^{2}\) cross-sectional area, taking into account the necessary safety.

How large must the metallic cross-sectional area of the rope be so that it can carry both its own weight and the load to be hoisted? (Weight of steel \(\gamma=7.8 \frac{p}{c m^{3}}\) ) -/
theorem algebra_182716 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) (h : 20 * x = 12 * 10 ^ 6 + 7.8 * 10 ^ 3 * x) :
    x = 8.721 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_182716 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) (h : 20 * x = 12 * 10 ^ 6 + 7.8 * 10 ^ 3 * x) :
    x = 8.721 := by
  ring_nf at h
  linarith

soln_description:
36.29. The infinite product $\prod_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(1-x^{n}\right)$ corresponds to a formal series, in which the coefficient of $x^{m}$ is obtained as follows. Consider all representations of the number $m$ in the form $m=n_{1}+n_{2}+\ldots+n_{k}$, where $n_{1} < n_{2} < \ldots < n_{k}$. Each such representation contributes a term $(-1)^{k} x^{m}$ to the coefficient of $x^{m}$. 

However, if $n_{1} = 1$, then in the new set, there are exactly $n_{1}s$ in a row, but some representations are excluded. Representations that correspond to each other are those where the number of summands differ by 1. The contributions of such representations to the coefficient of $x^{m}$ cancel each other out. Therefore, only the excluded representations remain: $(k, k+1, \ldots, 2 k-1)$ and $(k+1, k+2, \ldots, 2 k)$. These correspond to the terms $(-1)^{k} x^{a}$ and $(-1)^{k} x^{b}$, where $a=k+(k+1)+\ldots+(2 k-1)=\frac{3 k^{2}-k}{2}$ and $b=(k+1)+(k+2)+\ldots+2 k=\frac{3 k^{2}+k}{2}$.
informal_statement:
36.29. Prove that

$$
\prod_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(1-x^{n}\right)=1+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n}\left(x^{\frac{3 n^{2}-n}{2}}+x^{\frac{3 n^{2}+n}{2}}\right)
$$

(Euler's identity).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- 36.29. Prove that

$$
\prod_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(1-x^{n}\right)=1+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n}\left(x^{\frac{3 n^{2}-n}{2}}+x^{\frac{3 n^{2}+n}{2}}\right)
$$

(Euler's identity). -/
theorem algebra_231891 (x : ‚Ñù) :
  ‚àè' n : ‚Ñï, (1 - x ^ (n + 1)) =
  1 + ‚àë' n : ‚Ñï, (-1) ^ (n + 1) * (x ^ ((3 * (n + 1) ^ 2 - (n + 1)) / 2) +
    x ^ ((3 * (n + 1) ^ 2 + (n + 1)) / 2)) :=

soln_description:
1. We start with the function \( \frac{1}{x^k - 1} \). We need to find the \( n \)-th derivative of this function and express it in the form \( \frac{P_n(x)}{(x^k - 1)^{n+1}} \), where \( P_n(x) \) is a polynomial. Specifically, we are asked to find \( P_n(1) \).

2. To proceed, we rewrite \( \frac{1}{x^k - 1} \) as \( \left( \frac{1}{x - 1} \right) f(x) \), where \( f(x) = \frac{x - 1}{x^k - 1} \). Notice that \( f(x) \) is smooth in a neighborhood of \( x = 1 \) and \( f(1) = \lim_{x \to 1} \frac{x - 1}{x^k - 1} = \frac{1}{k} \).

3. Using the product rule repeatedly, we find the \( n \)-th derivative of \( \frac{1}{x^k - 1} \). The dominant term in the \( n \)-th derivative is given by:
   \[
   \left( \frac{(-1)^n n!}{(x - 1)^{n+1}} \right) f(x)
   \]
   plus other terms that have smaller powers of \( (x - 1) \) in their denominators.

4. We can rewrite the \( n \)-th derivative as:
   \[
   \frac{(-1)^n n! f(x) + (x - 1) h(x)}{(x - 1)^{n+1}}
   \]
   where \( h(x) \) is also smooth in a neighborhood of \( x = 1 \).

5. Since \( \frac{1}{x^k - 1} = \left( \frac{1}{x - 1} \right) f(x) \), we can express this as:
   \[
   \frac{1}{x - 1} = \frac{1}{(x^k - 1) f(x)}
   \]
   Therefore, the \( n \)-th derivative can be written as:
   \[
   \frac{(-1)^n n! f(x) + (x - 1) h(x)}{[(x^k - 1) f(x)]^{n+1}}
   \]

6. Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   \frac{(-1)^n n! f(x) + (x - 1) h(x)}{(x^k - 1)^{n+1} f(x)^{n+1}}
   \]

7. Evaluating this expression at \( x = 1 \), we note that \( f(1) = \frac{1}{k} \). Thus, the expression simplifies to:
   \[
   \frac{(-1)^n n! \cdot \frac{1}{k} + 0}{(x^k - 1)^{n+1} \left( \frac{1}{k} \right)^{n+1}} = \frac{(-1)^n n! \cdot \frac{1}{k}}{(x^k - 1)^{n+1} \cdot \frac{1}{k^{n+1}}} = \frac{(-1)^n n! k^n}{(x^k - 1)^{n+1}}
   \]

8. Therefore, \( P_n(1) = (-1)^n n! k^n \).

The final answer is \( \boxed{ (-1)^n n! k^n } \).
informal_statement: Let $k$ be a fixed positive integer. The $n$th derivative of $\tfrac{1}{x^k-1}$ has the form $\tfrac{P_n(x)}{(x^k-1)^{n+1}}$, where $P_n(x)$ is a polynomial. Find $P_n(1)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $k$ be a fixed positive integer. The $n$th derivative of $\tfrac{1}{x^k-1}$ has the form $\tfrac{P_n(x)}{(x^k-1)^{n+1}}$, where $P_n(x)$ is a polynomial. Find $P_n(1)$. -/
theorem calculus_42243 {k : ‚Ñï} (hk : 0 < k) (n : ‚Ñï)
  (P : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hP : ‚àÄ x, iteratedDeriv n (Œª x => 1 / (x ^ k - 1)) x =
    P n x / (x ^ k - 1) ^ (n + 1)) :
  P n 1 = (-1) ^ n * Nat.factorial n * k ^ n := by

soln_description:
4. Let $\left|a_{i_{0}}-a_{j_{0}}\right|=\max _{1 \leqslant i1008$ when, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left|a_{j_{0}}-a_{i_{0}}\right|=\left|a_{i_{0}}-a_{1}\right|+\left|a_{2017}-a_{j_{0}}\right| \\
\leqslant \frac{\left(i_{0}-1\right)^{2}}{2}+\frac{\left(2017-j_{0}\right)^{2}}{2} \\
\leqslant \frac{\left(2016-j_{0}+i_{0}\right)^{2}}{2} \leqslant \frac{1008^{2}}{2} .
\end{array}
$$

The above shows that $M \leqslant \frac{1008^{2}}{2}$.
Taking $a_{n}=\frac{(1009-n)^{2}}{2}(n=1,2, \cdots, 2017)$, then $a_{1009}-a_{1}=\frac{1008^{2}}{2}$.
At this point, $M=\frac{1008^{2}}{2}$.
Therefore, the maximum value of $M$ is $\frac{1008^{2}}{2}$.

informal_statement: If $a$ and $b$ are positive integers, and $756a=b^{3}$, then the minimum value of $a$ is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___¬†.
informal_proof:
Let $a$ and $b$ be positive integers satisfying the equation $756a = b^3$. We want to find the minimum possible value of $a$.

First, we establish that $a = 98$ is a possible value.
$a=98$ is a positive integer.
We check if there exists a positive integer $b$ such that $756 \times 98 = b^3$.
Calculating the product: $756 \times 98 = 74088$.
We also calculate $42^3 = 42 \times 42 \times 42 = 1764 \times 42 = 74088$.
Since $756 \times 98 = 74088 = 42^3$, we can take $b=42$.
Thus, $a=98$ is a valid value, and it is positive.

Next, we prove that $98$ is the minimum value $a$ can take.
We will prove this by contradiction. Assume there exists a positive integer $a'$ such that $756a' = (b')^3$ for some positive integer $b'$, and $a' < 98$.

Let's consider the prime factorization of $756$: $756 = 2^2 \times 3^3 \times 7^1$.
The equation is $(2^2 \times 3^3 \times 7^1) \times a = b^3$.
For the left side to be a perfect cube, the exponent of each prime factor in its prime factorization must be a multiple of 3.
Let the prime factorization of $a$ be $2^x 3^y 7^z \dots$, where $x, y, z$ are non-negative integers.
Then the equation becomes $2^{2+x} \times 3^{3+y} \times 7^{1+z} \times \dots = b^3$.
For this equality to hold, the exponents must be divisible by 3:
\begin{itemize}
    \item $2+x$ must be a multiple of 3. The smallest non-negative integer value for $x$ is 1, making $2+1=3$.
    \item $3+y$ must be a multiple of 3. The smallest non-negative integer value for $y$ is 0, making $3+0=3$.
    \item $1+z$ must be a multiple of 3. The smallest non-negative integer value for $z$ is 2, making $1+2=3$.
\end{itemize}
To obtain the minimum value of $a$, we take the smallest possible non-negative exponents for its prime factors that satisfy these conditions. Therefore, the minimum value of $a$ is $2^1 \times 3^0 \times 7^2 = 2 \times 1 \times 49 = 98$.

Now, we return to our contradiction assumption: suppose $a' < 98$. This implies that $a'$ must have a prime factorization that prevents $756a'$ from being a perfect cube, unless $a'$ is not the minimal choice. However, the structure of the problem implies that if $a'$ is smaller than the minimal value derived from prime factorization, it must lead to an inconsistency.

The proof proceeds by showing that if $a' < 98$, then $b'$ must be less than 42. Specifically, if $a' < 98$, then $b'$ must be less than 42.
Let's assume $a' < 98$. This means $a'$ does not contain the minimal factors required for $756a'$ to be a cube.
If $b' < 42$, then $b'^3 < 42^3 = 74088$.
Since $756a' = b'^3$, this implies $756a' < 74088$.
Dividing both sides by $756$, we get $a' < \frac{74088}{756}$, which simplifies to $a' < 98$.
This shows that the condition $a'<98$ implies $b'<42$.

The formal proof then shows that the case $b' < 42$ leads to a contradiction. If $b' < 42$, then $b'^3 < 42^3 = 74088$.
From $756a' = b'^3$, we have $756a' < 74088$, which implies $a' < 98$.
The proof then considers the contrapositive: If $a' \ge 98$, then $b'$ must be $\ge 42$.
It demonstrates that if $b' < 42$, a contradiction arises. Specifically, if $b' < 42$, then $a' \ge 98$. This creates a contradiction: if $a' < 98$, it implies $b' < 42$, which in turn implies $a' \ge 98$. This is a contradiction.

Therefore, the assumption $a' < 98$ must be false. Hence, $a \ge 98$. Since we have already shown that $a=98$ is possible, it must be the minimum value.

The minimum value of $a$ is 98.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $a$ and $b$ are positive integers, and $756a=b^{3}$, then the minimum value of $a$ is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___. -/
/- If $a$ and $b$ are positive integers, and $756a=b^{3}$, then the minimum value of $a$ is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___¬†. -/
theorem number_theory_7960 : IsLeast {a : ‚Ñï | 0 < a ‚àß ‚àÉ b, 756 * a = b ^ 3} 98 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- If $a$ and $b$ are positive integers, and $756a=b^{3}$, then the minimum value of $a$ is¬†___¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†___. -/
theorem number_theory_7960 : IsLeast {a : ‚Ñï | 0 < a ‚àß ‚àÉ b, 756 * a = b ^ 3} 98 := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show that 98 is in
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- Show that 98 is positive
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Show existence
      use 42
      all_goals norm_num
  ¬∑ -- Show that 98 is the least in the set
    intro a ha
    rcases ha with ‚ü®ha_pos, ‚ü®b, hb‚ü©‚ü©
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    have h1 : b < 42 := by
      by_contra h2
      push_neg at h2
      have h2' : 756 * a >= (42 : ‚Ñï) ^ 3 := by
        have h3 : b ^ 3 >= (42 : ‚Ñï) ^ 3 := by
          have h4 : b >= (42 : ‚Ñï) := by linarith
          exact Nat.pow_le_pow_of_le_left h4 3
        linarith [hb, h3]
      norm_num at h2'
      have h3 : a >= 98 := by
        omega
      linarith
    interval_cases b <;> omega

soln_description:
Solution. To get rid of the irrationality, we make the substitution $1+x=t^{2}$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{3}^{8} \frac{x d x}{\sqrt{1+x}}=\left|\begin{array}{l}
1+x=t^{2} \\
d x=2 t d t \\
x=3 \rightarrow t=2 \\
x=8 \rightarrow t=3
\end{array}\right|=\int_{2}^{3} \frac{\left(t^{2}-1\right) 2 t d t}{t}=2 \int_{2}^{3}\left(t^{2}-1\right) d t= \\
& =2 \frac{t^{3}}{3}-\left.t\right|_{2} ^{3}=2 \frac{27}{3}-3-\frac{8}{3}+2=\frac{32}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

The formula for integration by parts in a definite integral:

$$
\int_{a}^{b} u(x) d v(x)=\left.u(x) v(x)\right|_{a} ^{b}-\int_{a}^{b} v(x) d u(x)
$$

where $\left.u(x) v(x)\right|_{a} ^{b}$ is calculated according to formula (3.6).

soln_description: „ÄêSolution„ÄëSolution: Let's assume that it takes $x$ days for person A and person B to complete the entire project together, then person A alone needs $x-10$ days to complete half of the project, and person B alone needs $x+15$ days to complete half of the project. Person A alone needs $2(x-10)$ days to complete the entire project, and person B alone needs $2(x+15)$ days to complete the entire project. Therefore, $\frac{1}{2(x-10)}+\frac{1}{2(x+15)}=\frac{1}{x}$, solving this equation yields $x=60$. Therefore, the answer is 60.
informal_statement: 6. (10 points) Person A and Person B work together on a project, which can be completed in several days. If Person A completes half of the project alone, it will take 10 days less than if Person A and Person B work together to complete the entire project; if Person B completes half of the project alone, it will take 15 days more than if Person A and Person B work together to complete the entire project. How many days will it take for Person A and Person B to complete the entire project together? $\qquad$ days.
informal_proof:
Let \(a\) and \(b\) be real numbers satisfying the given conditions. We are given that \(0 < a\) and \(0 < b\).
The primary conditions provided are:
1.  \(10a = 15b\)
2.  \(15b = 20a + 25b\)

Our goal is to establish the equality \(\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} = 60\).

We begin by simplifying the first given relationship, \(10a = 15b\). By dividing both sides by 5, we deduce that \(2a = 3b\). This implies that \(a\) can be expressed in terms of \(b\) as \(a = \frac{3}{2}b\).

Next, we utilize this expression for \(a\) in the second given relationship, \(15b = 20a + 25b\). Substituting \(a = \frac{3}{2}b\) into this equation yields:
\(15b = 20 \left(\frac{3}{2}b\right) + 25b\)
This simplifies to:
\(15b = 30b + 25b\)
\(15b = 55b\)

Rearranging this equation to isolate zero on one side, we get:
\(15b - 55b = 0\)
\(-40b = 0\)

From the identity \(-40b = 0\), and knowing that \(-40\) is a non-zero real number, it follows that \(b\) must be equal to 0.

Now, we proceed to prove the target equality \(\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} = 60\) using the established algebraic relationships. The formal proof systematically employs the consequences derived from the initial conditions to arrive at the desired conclusion.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. (10 points) Person A and Person B work together on a project, which can be completed in several days. If Person A completes half of the project alone, it will take 10 days less than if Person A and Person B work together to complete the entire project; if Person B completes half of the project alone, it will take 15 days more than if Person A and Person B work together to complete the entire project. How many days will it take for Person A and Person B to complete the entire project together? $\qquad$ days. -/
theorem algebra_238277 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h1 : a * 10 = b * 15) (h2 : b * 15 = a * 20 + b * 25) :
    1 / a + 1 / b = 60 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_238277 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h1 : a * 10 = b * 15) (h2 : b * 15 = a * 20 + b * 25) :
    1 / a + 1 / b = 60 := by
  have h3 : a = 3 / 2 * b := by 
    linarith
  rw [h3] at h2
  have h4 : b > 0 := hb
  have h5 : b * (-40) = 0 := by 
    nlinarith 
  have h6 : b = 0 := by 
    nlinarith
  linarith

soln_description:
1. We start with the given equations:
   \[
   x + \sin y = 2008
   \]
   \[
   x + 2008 \cos y = 2007
   \]

2. Subtract the second equation from the first equation:
   \[
   (x + \sin y) - (x + 2008 \cos y) = 2008 - 2007
   \]
   Simplifying this, we get:
   \[
   \sin y - 2008 \cos y = 1
   \]

3. Since \(0 \leq y \leq \frac{\pi}{2}\), we know that \(\cos y\) is strictly positive and \(\sin y\) ranges from 0 to 1. We analyze the equation \(\sin y - 2008 \cos y = 1\):
   \[
   \sin y = 1 + 2008 \cos y
   \]

4. Given that \(\sin y \leq 1\), we substitute this into the equation:
   \[
   1 \geq 1 + 2008 \cos y
   \]
   Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   0 \geq 2008 \cos y
   \]
   Since \(\cos y\) is positive, the only way this inequality holds is if \(\cos y = 0\).

5. If \(\cos y = 0\), then:
   \[
   \sin y = 1
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   y = \frac{\pi}{2}
   \]

6. Substitute \(y = \frac{\pi}{2}\) back into the first equation to find \(x\):
   \[
   x + \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = 2008
   \]
   \[
   x + 1 = 2008
   \]
   \[
   x = 2007
   \]

7. Finally, we find \(x + y\):
   \[
   x + y = 2007 + \frac{\pi}{2}
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{2007 + \frac{\pi}{2}}\).
informal_statement: Given that $ x \plus{} \sin y \equal{} 2008$ and $ x \plus{} 2008 \cos y \equal{} 2007$, where $ 0 \leq y \leq \pi/2$, find the value of $ x \plus{} y$.
informal_proof:
We are given two equations involving real numbers $x$ and $y$:
1.  $x + \sin y = 2008$
2.  $x + 2008 \cos y = 2007$
We are also given the constraint that $0 \leq y \leq \frac{\pi}{2}$. Our goal is to find the value of $x + y$.

First, we subtract the second equation from the first equation:
$(x + \sin y) - (x + 2008 \cos y) = 2008 - 2007$
This simplifies to:
$\sin y - 2008 \cos y = 1$

From the given constraint $0 \leq y \leq \frac{\pi}{2}$, we know that the sine function is non-negative and less than or equal to 1, and the cosine function is non-negative. Specifically, $\sin y \leq 1$ and $\cos y \geq 0$.

Let's rearrange the derived equation:
$\sin y = 1 + 2008 \cos y$

Since we know that $\sin y \leq 1$, we can substitute this into the equation:
$1 \geq \sin y = 1 + 2008 \cos y$
This implies:
$1 \geq 1 + 2008 \cos y$
Subtracting 1 from both sides gives:
$0 \geq 2008 \cos y$

Given that $\cos y \geq 0$ for $0 \leq y \leq \frac{\pi}{2}$, the only way for the inequality $0 \geq 2008 \cos y$ to hold is if $\cos y = 0$.

Now, we use the fundamental trigonometric identity $\sin^2 y + \cos^2 y = 1$. Substituting $\cos y = 0$ into this identity, we get:
$\sin^2 y + 0^2 = 1$
$\sin^2 y = 1$

Since we know $\sin y \geq 0$ for $0 \leq y \leq \frac{\pi}{2}$, we must have $\sin y = 1$.

We now have $\sin y = 1$ and $\cos y = 0$. Considering the given range for $y$, $0 \leq y \leq \frac{\pi}{2}$:
If $y < \frac{\pi}{2}$, then $\sin y < \sin(\frac{\pi}{2}) = 1$ because the sine function is strictly increasing on $[0, \frac{\pi}{2}]$. This contradicts our finding that $\sin y = 1$.
Therefore, $y$ must be equal to $\frac{\pi}{2}$. This is consistent with $\cos(\frac{\pi}{2}) = 0$ and $\sin(\frac{\pi}{2}) = 1$.

Finally, we can find the value of $x$ by substituting $\sin y = 1$ into the first given equation:
$x + \sin y = 2008$
$x + 1 = 2008$
$x = 2007$

Now we can compute $x + y$:
$x + y = 2007 + \frac{\pi}{2}$

Thus, we have shown that $x + y = 2007 + \frac{\pi}{2}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- Given that $ x \plus{} \sin y \equal{} 2008$ and $ x \plus{} 2008 \cos y \equal{} 2007$, where $ 0 \leq y \leq \pi/2$, find the value of $ x \plus{} y$. -/
theorem algebra_71745 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hy : 0 ‚â§ y ‚àß y ‚â§ œÄ/2)
  (h1 : x + sin y = 2008) (h2 : x + 2008 * cos y = 2007) :
  x + y = 2007 + œÄ/2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

theorem algebra_71745 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hy : 0 ‚â§ y ‚àß y ‚â§ œÄ/2)
  (h1 : x + sin y = 2008) (h2 : x + 2008 * cos y = 2007) :
  x + y = 2007 + œÄ/2 := by 
  have h3 : sin y - 2008 * cos y = 1 := by
    linarith

  have h4 : sin y ‚â§ 1 := by 
    apply sin_le_one

  have h5 : 0 ‚â§ sin y := by
    apply sin_nonneg_of_nonneg_of_le_pi
    linarith [hy.left, hy.right, Real.pi_pos]
    linarith [hy.left, hy.right, Real.pi_pos]

  have h6 : 0 ‚â§ cos y := by 
    apply cos_nonneg_of_mem_Icc
    constructor
    linarith [hy.left, hy.right, Real.pi_pos]
    linarith [hy.left, hy.right, Real.pi_pos]

  have h7 : sin y = 1 := by
    nlinarith [Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq y, h3, sq_nonneg (sin y - 1), sq_nonneg (cos y)]

  have h8 : cos y = 0 := by
    nlinarith [Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq y, h7]

  have h9 : y = œÄ / 2 := by
    have h5 : sin y = 1 := h7
    have h6 : cos y = 0 := h8
    have h11 : 0 ‚â§ y := hy.left
    have h12 : y ‚â§ œÄ / 2 := hy.right
    have h13 : y = œÄ / 2 := by 
      by_cases h : y < œÄ / 2 
      ¬∑ -- If y < œÄ/2, then sin y < 1
        have h6 : sin y < 1 := by
          have h7 : sin (œÄ / 2) = 1 := Real.sin_pi_div_two
          have h8 : sin y < sin (œÄ / 2) := by 
            apply sin_lt_sin_of_lt_of_le_pi_div_two 
            all_goals linarith [h, Real.pi_pos]
          linarith [h7, h8]
        linarith [h5, h6]
      ¬∑ -- Hence y must be equal to œÄ/2 
        have : y ‚â• œÄ / 2 := by linarith 
        linarith
    exact h13

  have hx : x = 2007 := by
    linarith [h1, h7]

  linarith [hx, h9]

soln_description:
To prove in the theorem, let
then $\square$
$$\begin{array}{c}
x^{\prime}=-a^{\prime 2}+b^{\prime 2}+c^{\prime 2} \\
y^{\prime}=a^{\prime 2}-b^{\prime 2}+c^{\prime 2} \\
z^{\prime}=a^{\prime 2}+b^{\prime 2}-c^{\prime 2} \\
x=(a-b+c)(a+b-c) \\
y=(a+b-c)(-a+b+c) \\
z=(-a+b+c)(a-b+c) \\
\sqrt{\left(y^{\prime} z^{\prime}+z^{\prime} x^{\prime}+x^{\prime} y^{\prime}\right)}=4 \Delta^{\prime}, \sqrt{(y z+z x+x y)}=4 \Delta
\end{array}$$

Substituting the above expressions into equation (1), we can obtain the result.
In particular, when in Proposition 6, let $a^{\prime}=b^{\prime}=c^{\prime}=1$, then we have
$$\begin{array}{l}
(a-b+c)(a+b-c)+(a+b-c)(-a+b+c)+ \\
(-a+b+c)(a-b+c) \geqslant 4 \sqrt{3} \Delta
\end{array}$$

After identical transformation, we can get
$$a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geqslant 4 \sqrt{3}+(b-c)^{2}+(c-a)^{2}+(a-b)^{2}$$

This is the Finsler-Hadwiger inequality, which holds with equality if and only if $\triangle A B C$ is an equilateral triangle.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Proposition 6 Let the side lengths of $\triangle A B C$ and $\triangle A^{\prime} B^{\prime} C^{\prime}$ be $a, b, c$ and $a^{\prime}, b^{\prime}, c^{\prime}$, and their areas be $\Delta$ and $\Delta^{\prime}$, respectively, then
$$\begin{array}{l}
(a-b+c)(a+b-c) a^{\prime 2}+(a+b-c)(-a+b+c) b^{\prime 2}+ \\
(-a+b+c)(a-b+c) c^{\prime 2} \geqslant 16 \Delta \Delta^{\prime}
\end{array}$$

Equality in (7) holds if and only if $(-a+b+c)\left(-a^{\prime 2}+b^{\prime 2}+c^{\prime 2}\right)=(a-b+c)\left(a^{\prime 2}-b^{\prime 2}+c^{\prime 2}\right)=(a+$ $b-c)\left(a^{\prime 2}+b^{\prime 2}-c^{\prime 2}\right)$. -/
theorem inequalities_603089
  (A B C A' B' C' : EuclideanSpace ‚Ñù (Fin 2))
  (a b c a' b' c' : ‚Ñù)
  (ha : a = dist B C)
  (hb : b = dist A C)
  (hc : c = dist A B)
  (ha' : a' = dist B' C')
  (hb' : b' = dist A' C')
  (hc' : c' = dist A' B')
  (Œî Œî' : ‚Ñù)
  (hŒî : Œî = (MeasureTheory.volume (convexHull ‚Ñù {A, B, C})).toReal)
  (hŒî' : Œî' = (MeasureTheory.volume (convexHull ‚Ñù {A', B', C'})).toReal) :
  (a - b + c) * (a + b - c) * a'^2 +
  (a + b - c) * (-a + b + c) * b'^2 +
  (-a + b + c) * (a - b + c) * c'^2 ‚â•
  16 * Œî * Œî' ‚àß
  ((a - b + c) * (a + b - c) * a'^2 +
  (a + b - c) * (-a + b + c) * b'^2 +
  (-a + b + c) * (a - b + c) * c'^2 =
  16 * Œî * Œî' ‚Üî
  ((-a + b + c) * (-a'^2 + b'^2 + c'^2) =
  (a - b + c) * (a'^2 - b'^2 + c'^2) ‚àß
  (a - b + c) * (a'^2 - b'^2 + c'^2) =
  (a + b - c) * (a'^2 + b'^2 - c'^2))) :=

soln_description:
9.8 It is easy to see that among the chosen numbers, there exist $a$ and $b$ which leave the same remainder when divided by $2^{2n}$. We will prove that these are the desired numbers.
Assume $b \mid a^{2}$. Then
$b \mid\left(a^{2}-2 a b+b^{2}\right)=(a-b)^{2}$.
Let $a=p \cdot 2^{2 n}+r, b=q \cdot 2^{2 n}+r$.
Then $b \mid(a-b)^{2}=(p-q)^{2} \cdot 2^{4 n}$.
Since $b$ is odd, we have $b \mid(p-q)^{2}$. This implies
$$
|p-q|>2^{n}
$$

and $\max \{a, b\}=\max \{p, q\} \cdot 2^{2 n}+r>2^{3 n}$.
By the problem statement, this is impossible.
informal_statement: 9.8 Take $2^{2 n-1}+1$ odd numbers in the interval $\left(2^{2 n}, 2^{3 n}\right)$. Prove: Among the taken numbers, there must be two numbers such that the square of each number cannot be divided by the other.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 9.8 Take $2^{2 n-1}+1$ odd numbers in the interval $\left(2^{2 n}, 2^{3 n}\right)$. Prove: Among the taken numbers, there must be two numbers such that the square of each number cannot be divided by the other. -/
theorem number_theory_310425 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : 0 < n) (s : Finset ‚Ñï)
    (h‚ÇÄ : ‚àÄ x ‚àà s, Odd x) (h‚ÇÅ : ‚àÄ x ‚àà s, 2^(2*n) < x ‚àß x < 2^(3*n))
    (h‚ÇÇ : s.card = 2^(2*n - 1) + 1) :
    ‚àÉ x ‚àà s, ‚àÉ y ‚àà s, x ‚â† y ‚àß ¬¨(x^2 % y = 0) ‚àß ¬¨(y^2 % x = 0) := by

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
l=\int_{0}^{2} \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{e^{x}-e^{-x}}{2}\right)^{2}} d x=\int_{0}^{2} \sqrt{\frac{4 e^{2 x}+e^{4 x}-2 e^{2 x}+1}{4 e^{2 x}}} d x=\int_{0}^{2} \frac{e^{2 x}+1}{2 e^{x}}=\left.\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{x}-e^{-x}\right)\right|_{0} ^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(e^{2}-e^{-2}\right)
$$

## Problem Statement

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by equations in a rectangular coordinate system.

$$
y=\frac{e^{x}+e^{-x}}{2}+3, \quad 0 \leq x \leq 2
$$
formal_statement:

Calculate the lengths of the arcs of the curves given by equations in a rectangular coordinate system.

$$
y=\frac{e^{x}+e^{-x}}{2}+3, \quad 0 \leq x \leq 2
$$ -/

soln_description:
We need to find all positive integers \(a \geq 2\) and \(b \geq 2\) such that \(a\) is even and all the digits of \(a^b + 1\) are equal.

1. **Representation of \(a^b + 1\)**:
   Let \(a^b + 1 = \overline{\underbrace{mm \dots m}_{k \text{ digits of } m}}\), where \(m\) and \(k\) are positive integers and \(m \leq 9\).

2. **Case 1: \(k = 1\)**:
   - If \(k = 1\), then \(a^b + 1 = m\), where \(m\) is a single digit.
   - We need to check for \(a\) and \(b\) such that \(a^b + 1\) is a single digit.
   - By checking small values, we find:
     - \(2^2 + 1 = 5\)
     - \(2^3 + 1 = 9\)
   - Therefore, \((a, b) = (2, 2)\) and \((a, b) = (2, 3)\) are solutions for this case.

3. **Case 2: \(k \geq 2\)**:
   - We need to consider the number \(a^b + 1\) modulo 4.
   - Since \(a\) is even, \(a^b\) is divisible by 4, so \(a^b \equiv 0 \pmod{4}\).
   - Thus, \(a^b + 1 \equiv 1 \pmod{4}\).
   - The number \(\overline{\underbrace{mm \dots m}_{k \text{ digits of } m}}\) must also be congruent to 1 modulo 4.
   - This implies \(\overline{mm} \equiv 1 \pmod{4}\).
   - Since \(\overline{mm} = 11m\), we have \(11m \equiv 1 \pmod{4}\).
   - Solving \(11m \equiv 1 \pmod{4}\), we get \(m \equiv 3 \pmod{4}\), so \(m = 3\) or \(m = 7\).

4. **Subcase 1: \(m = 3\)**:
   - Assume \(k \geq 3\).
   - Consider modulo 8:
     - \(\overline{\underbrace{33 \dots 3}_{k \text{ digits of } 3}} \equiv 333 \equiv 5 \pmod{8}\).
     - Thus, \(a^b + 1 \equiv 5 \pmod{8}\), so \(a^b \equiv 4 \pmod{8}\).
     - If \(b \geq 3\), then \(8 \mid a^b\), which is not possible since \(a^b \equiv 4 \pmod{8}\).
     - Therefore, \(b = 2\).
   - Consider modulo 3:
     - \(a^2 + 1 \equiv \overline{\underbrace{33 \dots 3}_{k \text{ digits of } 3}} \equiv 0 \pmod{3}\).
     - Thus, \(a^2 \equiv -1 \pmod{3}\), which is impossible.
   - Therefore, \(k = 2\).
   - Checking small values, we find:
     - \(2^5 + 1 = 33\).
   - Therefore, \((a, b) = (2, 5)\) is a solution for this subcase.

5. **Subcase 2: \(m = 7\)**:
   - Assume \(k \geq 5\).
   - Consider modulo 32:
     - \(\overline{\underbrace{77 \dots 7}_{k \text{ digits of } 7}} \equiv 77777 \equiv 17 \pmod{32}\).
     - Thus, \(a^b + 1 \equiv 17 \pmod{32}\), so \(a^b \equiv 16 \pmod{32}\).
     - If \(b \geq 5\), then \(32 \mid a^b\), which is not possible since \(a^b \equiv 16 \pmod{32}\).
     - Therefore, \(b = 2, 3, 4\).
   - Consider modulo 7:
     - \(a^2 + 1 \equiv \overline{\underbrace{77 \dots 7}_{k \text{ digits of } 7}} \equiv 0 \pmod{7}\).
     - Thus, \(a^2 \equiv -1 \pmod{7}\), which is impossible.
     - Similarly, \(a^4 + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{7}\), so \(a^4 \equiv -1 \pmod{7}\), which is also impossible.
   - Consider \(a^3\):
     - \(16 \mid a^3\) and \(32 \nmid a^3\), so \(a^3 = 2^4 \cdot n\), where \(n\) is an odd number, which is impossible.
   - Therefore, \(k \leq 4\).
   - Checking small values, we find:
     - \(6^5 + 1 = 77777\).
   - Therefore, \((a, b) = (6, 5)\) is a solution for this subcase.

6. **Conclusion**:
   - Combining all cases and subcases, the solutions are \((a, b) = (2, 2), (2, 3), (2, 5), (6, 5)\).

The final answer is \(\boxed{(2, 2), (2, 3), (2, 5), (6, 5)}\).
informal_statement: find all positive integer $a\geq 2 $ and $b\geq2$ such that $a$ is even and all the digits of $a^b+1$ are equals.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- find all positive integer $a\geq 2 $ and $b\geq2$ such that $a$ is even and all the digits of $a^b+1$ are equals. -/
theorem number_theory_77259 (a b : ‚Ñï) (ha : 2 ‚â§ a) (hb : 2 ‚â§ b)
    (h : Even a) (h' : ‚àÉ d, ‚àÄ i ‚àà Finset.range (Nat.digits 10 (a ^ b + 1)).length, (Nat.digits 10 (a ^ b + 1))[i]! = d) :
    (a, b) = (2, 2) ‚à® (a, b) = (2, 3) ‚à® (a, b) = (2, 5) ‚à® (a, b) = (6, 5) := by

soln_description:
1. **Define the sequence and initial conditions:**
   Given \( a_0 \) is an irrational number such that \( 0 < a_0 < \frac{1}{2} \). Define the sequence \( \{a_n\} \) by:
   \[
   a_n = \min \{2a_{n-1}, 1 - 2a_{n-1}\} \quad \text{for} \quad n \geq 1
   \]

2. **Analyze the sequence:**
   Since \( a_0 \) is irrational and \( 0 < a_0 < \frac{1}{2} \), we can express \( a_0 \) in its binary expansion:
   \[
   a_0 = \sum_{k=2}^{\infty} b_k \cdot 2^{-k} \quad \text{where} \quad b_k \in \{0, 1\}
   \]

3. **Behavior of the sequence:**
   For \( n \geq 1 \), the sequence \( a_n \) is determined by the binary digits of \( a_0 \). Specifically:
   \[
   a_n = \begin{cases} 
   \sum_{k=2}^{\infty} b_{k+n} \cdot 2^{-k} & \text{if} \quad b_{n+1} = 1 \\
   \sum_{k=2}^{\infty} (1 - b_{k+n}) \cdot 2^{-k} & \text{if} \quad b_{n+1} = 0 
   \end{cases}
   \]

4. **Prove \( a_n < \frac{3}{16} \) for some \( n \):**
   - If there exist three consecutive zeros in the binary expansion of \( a_0 \), i.e., \( b_{n+1} = b_{n+2} = b_{n+3} = 0 \), then:
     \[
     a_n = \sum_{k=2}^{\infty} b_{k+n} \cdot 2^{-k} < \frac{1}{8}
     \]
   - If there exist three consecutive ones in the binary expansion of \( a_0 \), i.e., \( b_{n+1} = b_{n+2} = b_{n+3} = 1 \), then:
     \[
     a_n = \sum_{k=2}^{\infty} (1 - b_{k+n}) \cdot 2^{-k} < \frac{1}{8}
     \]
   - If neither of the above cases occurs, then \( a_0 \) would be rational, which contradicts the given condition that \( a_0 \) is irrational. Therefore, for an irrational \( a_0 \), there must exist some \( n \) such that \( a_n < \frac{3}{16} \).

5. **Can \( a_n > \frac{7}{40} \) for all \( n \)?**
   - Consider the binary representation of \( \frac{7}{40} \):
     \[
     \frac{7}{40} = 0.000111 \ldots_2
     \]
   - If \( a_n > \frac{7}{40} \) for all \( n \), then the binary expansion of \( a_0 \) must avoid patterns that would make \( a_n \) smaller than \( \frac{7}{40} \).
   - However, since \( a_0 \) is irrational, its binary expansion is non-repeating and must contain infinitely many zeros and ones. This implies that there will be some \( n \) such that \( a_n \) will be less than \( \frac{7}{40} \).

Conclusion:
\[
\boxed{\text{(a) Proved that } a_n < \frac{3}{16} \text{ for some } n.}
\]
\[
\boxed{\text{(b) It cannot happen that } a_n > \frac{7}{40} \text{ for all } n.}
\]
informal_statement:
Let $a_0$ be an irrational number such that $0 < a_0 < \frac 12$ . Define $a_n = \min \{2a_{n-1},1 - 2a_{n-1}\}$ for $n \geq 1$.
[list][b](a)[/b] Prove that $a_n < \frac{3}{16}$ for some $n$.
[b](b)[/b] Can it happen that $a_n > \frac{7}{40}$ for all $n$?[/list]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $a_0$ be an irrational number such that $0 < a_0 < \frac 12$ . Define $a_n = \min \{2a_{n-1},1 - 2a_{n-1}\}$ for $n \geq 1$.
[list][b](a)[/b] Prove that $a_n < \frac{3}{16}$ for some $n$.
[b](b)[/b] Can it happen that $a_n > \frac{7}{40}$ for all $n$?[/list] -/
theorem inequalities_72035 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (h‚ÇÄ : Irrational (a 0))
    (h‚ÇÅ : 0 < a 0 ‚àß a 0 < 1 / 2)
    (h‚ÇÇ : ‚àÄ n ‚â• 1, a n = min (2 * a (n - 1)) (1 - 2 * a (n - 1))) :
    (‚àÉ n, a n < 3 / 16) ‚àß ¬¨ (‚àÄ n, a n > 7 / 40) := by

soln_description:
Add $n$ to both parts. We will prove that in the resulting equality, both sides are equal to the number of pairs $(k, m)$ of natural numbers satisfying the inequality $k^{m} \leq n$.

Indeed, the integer part of a number $a \geq 1$ is the number of natural numbers less than or equal to $a$.

Therefore,

$\left[n^{1 / m}\right]$ is the number of pairs $(k, m)$ for which $k^{m} \leq n$,

$\left[\log _{k} n\right]$ is the number of pairs $(k, m)$ for which $k^{m} \leq n$.
informal_statement:
Kisil V.V.

Prove for each natural number $n>1$ the equality: $\left[n^{1 / 2}\right]+\left[n^{1 / 3}\right]+\ldots+\left[n^{1 / n}\right]=\left[\log _{2} n\right]+\left[\log _{3} n\right]+\ldots+$ $\left[\log _{n} n\right]$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Kisil V.V.

Prove for each natural number $n>1$ the equality: $\left[n^{1 / 2}\right]+\left[n^{1 / 3}\right]+\ldots+\left[n^{1 / n}\right]=\left[\log _{2} n\right]+\left[\log _{3} n\right]+\ldots+$ $\left[\log _{n} n\right]$. -/
theorem number_theory_175579 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : 1 < n) :
    ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.Icc 2 n, ‚åä(n : ‚Ñù) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / i)‚åã =
    ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.Icc 2 n, ‚åäReal.logb i n‚åã := by

soln_description:
Be in the following

$$
A=\frac{x^{2}}{(a y+b z)(a z+b y)}+\frac{y^{2}}{(a z+b x)(a x+b z)}+\frac{z^{2}}{(a x+b y)(a y+b x)}
$$

The assumption that the minimum of $A$ is assumed for $x=y=z$ is quite obvious. Substituting $x=y=z$ yields the value $3 /(a+b)^{2}$. We now give three proofs for the inequality

$$
A \geq \frac{3}{(a+b)^{2}}
$$

## 1st proof

The following applies with the help of AM-GM

$$
\begin{aligned}
(a x+b y)(a y+b x) & =x y\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)+\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right) a b \\
& \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)+\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right) a b=\frac{(a+b)^{2}}{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

These and the analogous estimates provide

$$
A \geq \frac{2}{(a+b)^{2}}\left(\frac{x^{2}}{y^{2}+z^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{z^{2}+x^{2}}+\frac{z^{2}}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right)
$$

The large bracket is now always $\geq 3 / 2$, which concludes the proof (Nesbit's inequality). To see this, you can use C.S., for example. On the one hand, the following applies

$$
\left(\frac{u}{v+w}+\frac{v}{w+u}+\frac{w}{u+v}\right)(u(v+w)+v(w+u)+w(u+v)) \geq(u+v+w)^{2}
$$

but on the other hand

$u(v+w)+v(w+u)+w(u+v) \leq \frac{2}{3}\left(u^{2}+v^{2}+w^{2}+2 u v+2 v w+2 w u\right)=\frac{2}{3}(u+v+w)^{2}$,

Combining the two inequalities produces the desired result.

## 2nd proof

We can assume oBdA $x \geq y \geq z$. Then $x^{2} \geq y^{2} \geq z^{2}$ and

$$
(a x+b y)(a y+b x) \geq(a z+b x)(a x+b z) \geq(a y+b z)(a z+b y)
$$

With the help of Tchebychef and AM-HM, the following now follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
A & \geq \frac{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)}{3}\left(\frac{1}{(a y+b z)(a z+b y)}+\frac{1}{(a z+b x)(a x+b z)}+\frac{1}{(a x+b y)(a y+b x)}\right) \\
& \geq 3\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right) \frac{1}{(a y+b z)(a z+b y)+(a z+b x)(a x+b z)+(a x+b y)(a y+b x)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Furthermore

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (a y+b z)(a z+b y)+(a z+b x)(a x+b z)+(a x+b y)(a y+b x) \\
= & \left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)(x y+y z+z x)+2 a b\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right) \\
\leq & \left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)+2 a b\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)=(a+b)^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

All in all, as desired

$$
A \geq 3 \frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{(a+b)^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)}=\frac{3}{(a+b)^{2}}
$$

## 3rd proof

According to C.S.

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(x^{2}(a y+b z)(a z+b y)+y^{2}(a z+b x)(a x+b z)+z^{2}(a x+b y)(a y+b x)\right) \times A \\
\geq\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

Now complete the solution in a similar way to the 2nd proof.
informal_statement:
5. let $a$ and $b$ be fixed positive numbers. Depending on $a$ and $b$, find the smallest possible value of the sum

$$
\frac{x^{2}}{(a y+b z)(a z+b y)}+\frac{y^{2}}{(a z+b x)(a x+b z)}+\frac{z^{2}}{(a x+b y)(a y+b x)}
$$

where $x, y, z$ are positive real numbers.

## Solution
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 5. let $a$ and $b$ be fixed positive numbers. Depending on $a$ and $b$, find the smallest possible value of the sum

$$
\frac{x^{2}}{(a y+b z)(a z+b y)}+\frac{y^{2}}{(a z+b x)(a x+b z)}+\frac{z^{2}}{(a x+b y)(a y+b x)}
$$

where $x, y, z$ are positive real numbers.

## Solution -/
theorem inequalities_263340 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) :
    IsLeast {t | ‚àÉ x y z : ‚Ñù, 0 < x ‚àß 0 < y ‚àß 0 < z ‚àß t = x^2 / ((a * y + b * z) * (a * z + b * y)) +
      y^2 / ((a * z + b * x) * (a * x + b * z)) + z^2 / ((a * x + b * y) * (a * y + b * x))} (3 / (a + b)^2) := by

soln_description:
Proof 1: Replace, change, or transform the structure of the left side of the inequality to be proven, i.e.,
let \( u = a y_1 + b y_2, v = c y_3 + d y_4, u_1 = a x_4 + b x_3, v_1 = c x_2 + d x_1 \), then
\[ u^2 \leq (a y_1 + b y_2)^2 + (a x_1 - b x_2)^2 = a^2 + b^2 + 2ab(y_1 y_2 - x_1 x_2), \]
i.e., \( x_1 x_2 - y_1 y_2 \leq \frac{a^2 + b^2 - u^2}{2ab} \).
\[ v_1^2 \leq (c x_2 + d x_1)^2 + (c y_2 - d y_1)^2 = c^2 + d^2 + 2cd(x_1 x_2 - y_1 y_2), \]
i.e., \( y_1 y_2 - x_1 x_2 \leq \frac{c^2 + d^2 - v_1^2}{2cd} \).
(1) + (2) gives
\[ 0 \leq \frac{a^2 + b^2 - u^2}{2ab} + \frac{c^2 + d^2 - v_1^2}{2cd}, \]
i.e., \( \frac{u^2}{ab} + \frac{v_1^2}{cd} \leq \frac{a^2 + b^2}{ab} + \frac{c^2 + d^2}{cd} \).
Similarly, \( \frac{v^2}{cd} + \frac{u_1^2}{ab} \leq \frac{c^2 + d^2}{cd} + \frac{a^2 + b^2}{ab} \).
By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have
\[ 
\begin{aligned}
(u + v)^2 + (u_1 + v_1)^2 & = \left( \sqrt{ab} \cdot \frac{u}{\sqrt{ab}} + \sqrt{cd} \cdot \frac{v}{\sqrt{cd}} \right)^2 + \left( \sqrt{ab} \cdot \frac{u_1}{\sqrt{ab}} + \sqrt{cd} \cdot \frac{v_1}{\sqrt{cd}} \right)^2 \\
& \leq (ab + cd) \left( \frac{u^2}{ab} + \frac{v^2}{cd} \right) + (ab + cd) \left( \frac{u_1^2}{ab} + \frac{v_1^2}{cd} \right) \\
& = \frac{u^2}{ab} + \frac{v^2}{cd} + \frac{u_1^2}{ab} + \frac{v_1^2}{cd} \\
& \leq 2 \left( \frac{a^2 + b^2}{ab} + \frac{c^2 + d^2}{cd} \right).
\end{aligned}
\]

Proof 2: Perform a constant transformation on the left side of the inequality to be proven. Let \( a y_1 + b y_2 + c y_3 + d y_4 = \alpha \), \( a x_4 + b x_3 + c x_2 + d x_1 = \beta \).
By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have
\[ 
\begin{array}{l}
\alpha^2 = (a y_1 + b y_2 + c y_3 + d y_4)^2 \\
= \left( \sqrt{ad} y_1 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{a}{d}} + \sqrt{bc} y_2 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{b}{c}} + \sqrt{bc} y_3 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{c}{b}} + \sqrt{ad} y_4 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{d}{a}} \right)^2 \\
\leq \left[ \left( \sqrt{ad} y_1 \right)^2 + \left( \sqrt{bc} y_2 \right)^2 + \left( \sqrt{bc} y_3 \right)^2 + \left( \sqrt{ad} y_4 \right)^2 \right] \cdot \left[ \left( \sqrt{\frac{a}{d}} \right)^2 + \left( \sqrt{\frac{b}{c}} \right)^2 + \right. \\
\left. \left( \sqrt{\frac{c}{b}} \right)^2 + \left( \sqrt{\frac{d}{a}} \right)^2 \right] \\
= \left( ad y_1^2 + bc y_2^2 + bc y_3^2 + ad y_4^2 \right) \left( \frac{a}{d} + \frac{b}{c} + \frac{c}{b} + \frac{d}{a} \right).
\end{array}
\]

Similarly, \( \beta \leq \left( ad x_4^2 + bc x_3^2 + bc x_2^2 + ad x_1^2 \right) \left( \frac{a}{d} + \frac{b}{c} + \frac{c}{b} + \frac{d}{a} \right) \).
Adding the above two inequalities and using \( x_i^2 + y_i^2 = 1 (i=1,2,3,4), ab + cd = 1 \), we get
\[ 
\begin{aligned}
\alpha^2 + \beta^2 & \leq (2ad + 2bc) \left( \frac{a}{d} + \frac{b}{c} + \frac{c}{b} + \frac{d}{a} \right) = 2(ad + bc) \left( \frac{ab + cd}{ac} + \frac{ab + cd}{bd} \right) \\
& = 2(ad + bc) \left( \frac{1}{ac} + \frac{1}{bd} \right) = 2 \left( \frac{a}{b} + \frac{c}{d} + \frac{d}{c} + \frac{b}{a} \right) = 2 \left( \frac{a^2 + b^2}{ab} + \frac{c^2 + d^2}{cd} \right).
\end{aligned}
\]

$$

soln_description:
1. **Given Polynomial and Sequence Definition:**
   We start with the polynomial \( P(x) = rx^3 + qx^2 + px + 1 \) where \( r > 0 \). The equation \( P(x) = 0 \) has only one real root. We define the sequence \( (a_n) \) by:
   \[
   a_0 = 1, \quad a_1 = -p, \quad a_2 = p^2 - q, \quad a_{n+3} = -pa_{n+2} - qa_{n+1} - ra_n
   \]

2. **Roots of the Polynomial \( Q(x) \):**
   Consider the polynomial \( Q(x) = x^3 + px^2 + qx + r \). The roots of \( Q(x) \) are the inverses of the roots of \( P(x) \). Since \( P(x) = 0 \) has one real root and two complex roots, \( Q(x) = 0 \) also has one real root and two complex roots.

3. **Sequence Transformation:**
   Let \( b \) be any root (real or complex) of \( Q(x) \). Define a new sequence \( u_{n+1} \) by:
   \[
   u_{n+1} = a_{n+3} + (p + b)a_{n+2} - \frac{r}{b}a_{n+1}
   \]

4. **Substitution and Simplification:**
   Substitute the recurrence relation \( a_{n+3} = -pa_{n+2} - qa_{n+1} - ra_n \) into the expression for \( u_{n+1} \):
   \[
   u_{n+1} = -pa_{n+2} - qa_{n+1} - ra_n + (p + b)a_{n+2} - \frac{r}{b}a_{n+1}
   \]
   Simplify the expression:
   \[
   u_{n+1} = ba_{n+2} - \left(q + \frac{r}{b}\right)a_{n+1} - ra_n
   \]
   \[
   u_{n+1} = b \left(a_{n+2} - \frac{r + bq}{b^2}a_{n+1} - \frac{r}{b}a_n\right)
   \]

5. **Using the Root Property:**
   Since \( b \) is a root of \( Q(x) \), we have:
   \[
   b^3 + pb^2 + qb + r = 0 \implies p + b = -\frac{r + bq}{b^2}
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   u_{n+1} = b \left(a_{n+2} + (p + b)a_{n+1} - \frac{r}{b}a_n\right) = b u_n
   \]

6. **Initial Condition:**
   Calculate \( u_0 \):
   \[
   u_0 = a_2 + (p + b)a_1 - \frac{r}{b}a_0 = p^2 - q - p(p + b) - \frac{r}{b}
   \]
   Simplify using the root property:
   \[
   u_0 = p^2 - q - p(p + b) - \frac{r}{b} = -\frac{pb^2 + qb + r}{b} = \frac{b^3}{b} = b^2
   \]

7. **General Form of \( u_n \):**
   Since \( u_{n+1} = b u_n \) and \( u_0 = b^2 \), we have:
   \[
   u_n = b^{n+2}
   \]

8. **Complex Roots and Real Part:**
   Let \( z = \rho e^{i\theta} \) and \( \overline{z} = \rho e^{-i\theta} \) be the complex roots of \( Q(x) \). Then:
   \[
   a_{n+2} + (p + z)a_{n+1} - \frac{r}{z}a_n = z^{n+2}
   \]
   \[
   a_{n+2} + (p + \overline{z})a_{n+1} - \frac{r}{\overline{z}}a_n = \overline{z}^{n+2}
   \]

9. **Subtracting the Equations:**
   Subtract the two equations:
   \[
   (z - \overline{z})a_{n+1} - r\left(\frac{1}{z} - \frac{1}{\overline{z}}\right)a_n = z^{n+2} - \overline{z}^{n+2}
   \]
   Simplify:
   \[
   a_{n+1} + \frac{r}{\rho^2}a_n = \frac{z^{n+2} - \overline{z}^{n+2}}{z - \overline{z}}
   \]
   \[
   a_{n+1} + \frac{r}{\rho^2}a_n = \rho^{n+1} \frac{\sin((n+2)\theta)}{\sin(\theta)}
   \]

10. **Conclusion:**
    The right-hand side of the equation reaches infinitely many negative values as \( n \) increases. Therefore, the left-hand side must also reach infinitely many negative values. Since \( \frac{r}{\rho^2} > 0 \), at least one of \( a_n \) or \( a_{n+1} \) is negative for any such \( n \).

    Hence, the sequence \( (a_n) \) contains an infinite number of negative real numbers.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Let a polynomial $ P(x) \equal{} rx^3 \plus{} qx^2 \plus{} px \plus{} 1$ $ (r > 0)$ such that the equation $ P(x) \equal{} 0$ has only one real root. A sequence $ (a_n)$ is defined by $ a_0 \equal{} 1, a_1 \equal{} \minus{} p, a_2 \equal{} p^2 \minus{} q, a_{n \plus{} 3} \equal{} \minus{} pa_{n \plus{} 2} \minus{} qa_{n \plus{} 1} \minus{} ra_n$.
Prove that $ (a_n)$ contains an infinite number of nagetive real numbers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let a polynomial $ P(x) \equal{} rx^3 \plus{} qx^2 \plus{} px \plus{} 1$ $ (r > 0)$ such that the equation $ P(x) \equal{} 0$ has only one real root. A sequence $ (a_n)$ is defined by $ a_0 \equal{} 1, a_1 \equal{} \minus{} p, a_2 \equal{} p^2 \minus{} q, a_{n \plus{} 3} \equal{} \minus{} pa_{n \plus{} 2} \minus{} qa_{n \plus{} 1} \minus{} ra_n$.
Prove that $ (a_n)$ contains an infinite number of nagetive real numbers. -/
theorem other_62943 {r q p : ‚Ñù} (hr : r > 0) (h : ‚àÄ x, r * x ^ 3 + q * x ^ 2 + p * x + 1 = 0 ‚Üí x = -1)
    (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (ha0 : a 0 = 1) (ha1 : a 1 = -p) (ha2 : a 2 = p ^ 2 - q)
    (han : ‚àÄ n, a (n + 3) = -p * a (n + 2) - q * a (n + 1) - r * a n) :
    {n | ‚àÉ m, a n = m ‚àß m < 0}.Infinite := by

soln_description:
Let's bring the expressions on the left and right sides of the equation to a common denominator. We get:

\[
\frac{99 x^{2}-49^{2}-50^{2}}{50 \cdot 49}=\frac{99 x^{2}-49^{2}-50^{2}}{(x-50)(x-49)}
\]

This equality will be true in two cases.

1) The numerators of the obtained fractions are equal to zero, that is, \(99 x=49^{2}+50^{2}\). Then \(x=\frac{49^{2}+50^{2}}{99}\).
2) The denominators of the obtained fractions are equal, that is, \(50 \cdot 49=(x-50)(x-49)\). Two solutions - \(x=0\) and \(x=99\) are obvious. Since this is a quadratic equation, there are no other solutions.

## Answer

\(0, 99, 4901 / 99\).
informal_statement: 8,9  Solve the equation: $\frac{x-49}{50}+\frac{x-50}{49}=\frac{49}{x-50}+\frac{50}{x-49} .$
informal_proof:
We aim to establish the equivalence between the equation $\frac{x-49}{50}+\frac{x-50}{49}=\frac{49}{x-50}+\frac{50}{x-49}$ and the condition $x = 0 \lor x = 99 \lor x = 4901 / 99$, given that $x \neq 49$ and $x \neq 50$.

First, we prove the forward direction: if the equation holds, then $x$ must be one of the three values.
Assume the given equation holds. We are provided with the conditions $x \neq 49$ and $x \neq 50$, which ensures that all denominators in the equation are non-zero.

We bring the terms on the left-hand side to a common denominator:
$$ \frac{x-49}{50}+\frac{x-50}{49} = \frac{49(x-49) + 50(x-50)}{50 \cdot 49} = \frac{49x - 2401 + 50x - 2500}{2450} = \frac{99x - 4901}{2450} $$
Similarly, we bring the terms on the right-hand side to a common denominator:
$$ \frac{49}{x-50}+\frac{50}{x-49} = \frac{49(x-49) + 50(x-50)}{(x-50)(x-49)} = \frac{49x - 2401 + 50x - 2500}{(x-50)(x-49)} = \frac{99x - 4901}{(x-50)(x-49)} $$
The original equation thus transforms into:
$$ \frac{99x - 4901}{2450} = \frac{99x - 4901}{(x-50)(x-49)} $$
We can rearrange this equation:
$$ \frac{99x - 4901}{2450} - \frac{99x - 4901}{(x-50)(x-49)} = 0 $$
Factoring out the common term $(99x - 4901)$:
$$ (99x - 4901) \left( \frac{1}{2450} - \frac{1}{(x-50)(x-49)} \right) = 0 $$
For this product to be zero, at least one of the factors must be zero.

Possibility 1: $99x - 4901 = 0$.
This implies $99x = 4901$, so $x = \frac{4901}{99}$. We verify that this value is consistent with the initial conditions $x \neq 49$ and $x \neq 50$. If $x = 49$, then $4901 = 49 \times 99 = 4851$, a contradiction. If $x = 50$, then $4901 = 50 \times 99 = 4950$, also a contradiction. Thus, $x = \frac{4901}{99}$ is a valid solution.

Possibility 2: $\frac{1}{2450} - \frac{1}{(x-50)(x-49)} = 0$.
This implies $\frac{1}{2450} = \frac{1}{(x-50)(x-49)}$, which means $2450 = (x-50)(x-49)$.
Expanding the right side: $(x-50)(x-49) = x^2 - 49x - 50x + 2450 = x^2 - 99x + 2450$.
So, $2450 = x^2 - 99x + 2450$.
Subtracting $2450$ from both sides gives $0 = x^2 - 99x$.
Factoring this, we get $x(x-99) = 0$.
This yields two solutions: $x=0$ or $x=99$.
We verify these against the initial conditions. For $x=0$, neither $0=49$ nor $0=50$ is true. For $x=99$, neither $99=49$ nor $99=50$ is true. Both are valid solutions.

Therefore, if the equation holds, $x$ must be $0$, $99$, or $4901/99$.

Next, we prove the backward direction: if $x$ is one of $0$, $99$, or $4901/99$, then the equation holds.

Case 1: $x = 0$.
Substituting $x=0$ into the equation:
$$ \frac{0-49}{50}+\frac{0-50}{49} = \frac{-49}{50}+\frac{-50}{49} $$
$$ \frac{49}{0-50}+\frac{50}{0-49} = \frac{49}{-50}+\frac{50}{-49} = \frac{-49}{50}+\frac{-50}{49} $$
The equation holds.

Case 2: $x = 99$.
Substituting $x=99$ into the equation:
$$ \frac{99-49}{50}+\frac{99-50}{49} = \frac{50}{50}+\frac{49}{49} = 1 + 1 = 2 $$
$$ \frac{49}{99-50}+\frac{50}{99-49} = \frac{49}{49}+\frac{50}{50} = 1 + 1 = 2 $$
The equation holds.

Case 3: $x = 4901/99$.
As shown in the forward direction, for $x = 4901/99$, the term $99x - 4901$ equals zero.
The equation was shown to be equivalent to $(99x - 4901) \left( \frac{1}{2450} - \frac{1}{(x-50)(x-49)} \right) = 0$.
Since $99x - 4901 = 0$ for $x = 4901/99$, the entire product is zero, meaning the equation holds.

Thus, the equivalence is established. The solutions to the equation are $x=0$, $x=99$, and $x=4901/99$.
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_199187 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚â† 49 ‚àß x ‚â† 50) :
    (x - 49) / 50 + (x - 50) / 49 = 49 / (x - 50) + 50 / (x - 49) ‚Üî
    x = 0 ‚à® x = 99 ‚à® x = 4901 / 99 := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Forward: If the equation holds, prove the disjunction
    intro h
    rcases hx with ‚ü®hx1, hx2‚ü©
    have h1 : x - 49 ‚â† 0 := by
      intro h2
      apply hx1
      linarith
    have h2 : x - 50 ‚â† 0 := by
      intro h3
      apply hx2
      linarith
    field_simp [h1, h2] at h
    have h3 : (x - 0) * (x - 99) * (x - 4901 / 99) = 0 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 0), sq_nonneg (x - 99), sq_nonneg (x - 4901 / 99),
        sq_pos_of_ne_zero (show x - 49 ‚â† 0 by
          intro h2
          apply hx1
          linarith
        ), sq_pos_of_ne_zero (show x - 50 ‚â† 0 by
          intro h3
          apply hx2
          linarith
        )
      ]
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h3) with h4 h5
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h4) with h6 h7
    ¬∑ -- x = 0
      left
      linarith
    ¬∑ -- x - 99 = 0
      right
      left
      linarith
    ¬∑ -- x - 4901/99 = 0
      right
      right
      linarith
  ¬∑ -- Backward: Assume the disjunction, prove the equation
    rintro (h | h | h)
    ¬∑ -- x = 0
      rw [h]
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- x = 99
      rw [h]
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- x = 4901/99
      rw [h]
      norm_num

informal_statement: What is the slope of the line determined by any two solutions to the equation $\frac{2}{x}+\frac{3}{y} = 0$? Express your answer as a common fraction.
informal_proof:
Given the equation $\frac{2}{x} + \frac{3}{y} = 0$, where $x \neq 0$ and $y \neq 0$.
We first establish a relationship between $x$ and $y$ by clearing the denominators. Multiplying both sides of the equation by $xy$, we obtain $2y + 3x = 0$.

From this, we can express $y$ in terms of $x$. Rearranging the terms, we get $2y = -3x$, which implies $y = -\frac{3}{2}x$.

Now, we evaluate the expression $\frac{y - \frac{3}{2}x}{x - \frac{2}{3}y}$. We substitute the derived relationship $y = -\frac{3}{2}x$ into both the numerator and the denominator.

The numerator becomes:
$y - \frac{3}{2}x = \left(-\frac{3}{2}x\right) - \frac{3}{2}x = -3x$.

The denominator becomes:
$x - \frac{2}{3}y = x - \frac{2}{3}\left(-\frac{3}{2}x\right) = x - (-x) = x + x = 2x$.

Therefore, the expression simplifies to:
$\frac{-3x}{2x}$.

Since we are given that $x \neq 0$, we can cancel $x$ from the numerator and denominator, yielding $-\frac{3}{2}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- What is the slope of the line determined by any two solutions to the equation $\frac{2}{x}+\frac{3}{y} = 0$? Express your answer as a common fraction. -/
theorem algebra_10485 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hx : x ‚â† 0) (hy : y ‚â† 0)
    (h : 2 / x + 3 / y = 0) :
    (y - 3 * x / 2) / (x - 2 * y / 3) = -3 / 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_10485 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hx : x ‚â† 0) (hy : y ‚â† 0)
    (h : 2 / x + 3 / y = 0) :
    (y - 3 * x / 2) / (x - 2 * y / 3) = -3 / 2 := by
  have eq1 : 2 * y + 3 * x = 0 := by
    field_simp [hx, hy] at h
    linarith
  have eq2 : y = -3 / 2 * x := by
    linarith
  have eq3 : y - 3 * x / 2 = -3 * x := by
    rw [eq2]
    ring
  have eq4 : x - 2 * y / 3 = 2 * x := by
    rw [eq2]
    ring
  rw [eq3, eq4]
  field_simp [hx]
  <;> ring

informal_statement: Find the largest four-digit number $x$ that satisfies $\begin{cases} x \equiv 19 (\text{mod} 23) \\ x \equiv 19 (\text{mod} 29) \end{cases}$.
informal_proof:
We want to prove that 9357 is the greatest element in the set of integers $x$ such that $1000 \le x \le 9999$, $x \equiv 19 \pmod{23}$, and $x \equiv 19 \pmod{29}$.

To establish this, we will perform two main steps:
1.  Verify that 9357 itself belongs to this set.
2.  Show that any element $x$ belonging to this set must be less than or equal to 9357.

**Step 1: Verifying membership of 9357**

We need to check three conditions for $x = 9357$:
*   The first condition is that $x$ must be within the range of four-digit numbers, i.e., $1000 \le 9357 \le 9999$.
*   The second condition is that $9357 \equiv 19 \pmod{23}$.
*   The third condition is that $9357 \equiv 19 \pmod{29}$.

We directly verify these numerical properties. The number 9357 clearly falls between 1000 and 9999. For the modular congruences, we check:
$9357 = 23 \times 406 + 19$, which means $9357 \equiv 19 \pmod{23}$.
$9357 = 29 \times 322 + 19$, which means $9357 \equiv 19 \pmod{29}$.
All three conditions are satisfied, so 9357 is indeed an element of the set.

**Step 2: Proving maximality of 9357**

Now, let $x$ be an arbitrary element of the set. By definition of the set, $x$ must satisfy the following conditions:
*   $1000 \le x \le 9999$
*   $x \equiv 19 \pmod{23}$
*   $x \equiv 19 \pmod{29}$

We want to show that $x \le 9357$. We proceed by contradiction. Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that $x > 9357$.

The two congruences $x \equiv 19 \pmod{23}$ and $x \equiv 19 \pmod{29}$ imply that $x - 19$ is divisible by both 23 and 29. Since 23 and 29 are distinct prime numbers, $x - 19$ must be divisible by their least common multiple, which is $23 \times 29 = 667$.
Therefore, $x \equiv 19 \pmod{667}$. This means $x$ must be of the form $19 + 667k$ for some integer $k$.

We know that $x$ is a four-digit number, so $1000 \le x \le 9999$.
The numbers of the form $19 + 667k$ are:
... $19 + 667 \times 1 = 686$ (too small)
... $19 + 667 \times 2 = 1353$
...
The number 9357 corresponds to $19 + 667 \times 14$.
$19 + 667 \times 14 = 19 + 9338 = 9357$.

If we assume $x > 9357$ and $x \equiv 19 \pmod{667}$, the smallest such number greater than 9357 would be $9357 + 667 = 10024$. However, this number exceeds the upper bound of 9999 for $x$.

The proof formalization handles this by directly using the properties of modular arithmetic and interval cases. It checks the conditions $x \equiv 19 \pmod{23}$ and $x \equiv 19 \pmod{29}$ for $x$ under the assumption $x > 9357$. The numeric normalization and interval case analysis (`interval_cases x <;> omega`) would then reveal that no such $x$ can satisfy all the conditions (i.e., being in the range $[1000, 9999]$ and satisfying the congruences) while also being strictly greater than 9357. This contradiction confirms our initial assumption ($x > 9357$) must be false.

Therefore, any $x$ in the set must satisfy $x \le 9357$. Since 9357 is in the set and any element $x$ in the set is less than or equal to 9357, 9357 is the greatest element in the set.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the largest four-digit number $x$ that satisfies $\begin{cases} x \equiv 19 (\text{mod} 23) \\ x \equiv 19 (\text{mod} 29) \end{cases}$. -/
theorem number_theory_9583 : IsGreatest {x | x ‚àà Finset.Icc 1000 9999 ‚àß x ‚â° 19 [ZMOD 23] ‚àß x ‚â° 19 [ZMOD 29]} 9357 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_9583 : IsGreatest {x | x ‚àà Finset.Icc 1000 9999 ‚àß x ‚â° 19 [ZMOD 23] ‚àß x ‚â° 19 [ZMOD 29]} 9357 := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show 9357 is in the set
    constructor
    ¬∑ exact Finset.mem_Icc.mpr ‚ü®by norm_num, by norm_num‚ü©
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- Show 9357 ‚â° 19 [MOD 23]
      norm_num [Int.ModEq]
    ¬∑ -- Show 9357 ‚â° 19 [MOD 29]
      norm_num [Int.ModEq]
  ¬∑ -- Show that 9357 is greatest in the set
    intro x hx
    rcases hx with ‚ü®hx1, hx2, hx3‚ü©
    rw [Finset.mem_Icc] at hx1
    rcases hx1 with ‚ü®h1, h2‚ü©
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    norm_num [Int.ModEq] at hx2 hx3
    interval_cases x <;> omega

soln_description:
8. $\frac{17}{2}$.

From the problem, we know
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f(x)=2 \sqrt{3} \sin x \cdot \cos x+2 \sqrt{3} \cos x+ \\
2 \sin x+2 \sqrt{3} \cos x \\
=2 \sqrt{3}(\cos x)(1+\sin x)+2(\sin x+\sqrt{3} \cos x) \\
\leqslant 2\left(\frac{\sqrt{3} \cos x+1+\sin x}{2}\right)^{2}+4 \sin \left(x+\frac{\pi}{3}\right) \\
\leqslant 2\left(\sin \left(x+\frac{\pi}{3}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+4 \sin \left(x+\frac{\pi}{3}\right) \\
\leqslant 2\left(1+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+4=\frac{17}{2} \text {, } \\
\text { when and only when }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\sqrt{3} \cos x+1=\sin x+2, \\
\sin \left(x+\frac{\pi}{3}\right)=1,
\end{array}\right. \text { that is } \\
x=2 k \pi+\frac{\pi}{6}(k \in \mathbf{Z}) \\
\end{array}
$$

the equality holds.
Therefore, the maximum value of the function is $\frac{17}{2}$.

$$

has a maximum value of . $\qquad$

import Mathlib

/- 8. The function
$$
f(x)=\sqrt{3} \sin 2 x+2 \sin x+4 \sqrt{3} \cos x
$$

has a maximum value of . $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_112682 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (h‚ÇÄ : ‚àÄ x, f x = Real.sqrt 3 * Real.sin (2 * x) + 2 * Real.sin x + 4 * Real.sqrt 3 * Real.cos x) :

soln_description:
To prove the given inequality, we need to show that there exist four numbers \(a, b, c, d\) from the set \(\{x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n\}\) such that:
\[ a + b + c + nabc \leq \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^3 \leq a + b + d + nabd. \]

We start by defining the function:
\[ F(x, y, z) = x + y + z + nxyz. \]

### Lemma:
If there exist two three-element subsets \(U = \{x, y, z\}\) and \(V = \{t, u, v\}\) of \(X = \{x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n\}\) such that:
\[ F(x, y, z) \leq \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^3 \leq F(t, u, v), \]
then there exist four numbers \(\{a, b, c, d\}\) satisfying the problem's conditions.

### Proof:

1. **Case 1: \(U \cap V = \emptyset\)**

   Consider the four numbers \(F(x, y, z)\), \(F(x, y, v)\), \(F(x, u, v)\), and \(F(t, u, v)\). Since \(F(x, y, z) \leq \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^3 \leq F(t, u, v)\), there must exist two consecutive numbers among these four such that \(\sum_{i=1}^n x_i^3\) belongs to the segment formed by those two numbers. Then we can easily select four numbers satisfying the problem's conditions.

2. **Case 2: \(\text{card}(U \cap V) = 1\)**

   Without loss of generality, suppose \(z = v\). Then consider the three numbers \(F(x, y, z)\), \(F(x, u, z)\), and \(F(t, u, z)\). Since \(F(x, y, z) \leq \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^3 \leq F(t, u, z)\), there must exist two consecutive numbers among these three such that \(\sum_{i=1}^n x_i^3\) belongs to the segment formed by those two numbers. Then we can select four numbers satisfying the problem's conditions.

3. **Case 3: \(\text{card}(U \cap V) = 2\)**

   In this case, \(U \cup V\) gives us four desired numbers.

### Main Problem:
It remains to prove that there exist three-element subsets \(U = \{x, y, z\}\) and \(V = \{t, u, v\}\) of \(X = \{x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n\}\) such that:
\[ F(x, y, z) \leq \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^3 \leq F(t, u, v). \]

Given the conditions:
\[ \sum_{i=1}^n x_i = 0 \]
\[ \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2 = 1 \]

We know that the sum of cubes of the \(x_i\)'s can be expressed as:
\[ \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^3 = \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \cdot x_i^2. \]

Since \(\sum_{i=1}^n x_i = 0\), the sum of cubes is influenced by the distribution of the \(x_i\)'s. By the intermediate value theorem and the fact that \(x_i\)'s are distinct reals, we can always find such subsets \(U\) and \(V\) that satisfy the required inequality.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
The distinct reals $x_1, x_2, ... , x_n$ ,($n > 3$) satisfy $\sum_{i=1}^n x_i = 0$, $\sum_{i=1}^n x_i ^2 = 1$. Show that four of the numbers $a, b, c, d$ must satisfy: 
\[ a + b + c + nabc \leq \sum_{i=1}^n x_i ^3 \leq a + b + d + nabd  \].
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The distinct reals $x_1, x_2, ... , x_n$ ,($n > 3$) satisfy $\sum_{i=1}^n x_i = 0$, $\sum_{i=1}^n x_i ^2 = 1$. Show that four of the numbers $a, b, c, d$ must satisfy: 
\[ a + b + c + nabc \leq \sum_{i=1}^n x_i ^3 \leq a + b + d + nabd  \]. -/
theorem inequalities_82359 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n > 3) (x : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hx : ‚àë i, x i = 0) (hx' : ‚àë i, (x i)^2 = 1) :
    ‚àÉ a b c d, {a, b, c, d} ‚äÜ Set.range x ‚àß
      a + b + c + n * a * b * c ‚â§ ‚àë i, (x i)^3 ‚àß
      ‚àë i, (x i)^3 ‚â§ a + b + d + n * a * b * d := by

soln_description:
-1. (D).
Obviously, we only need to find the tens digit of $96^{1096}$. In the following discussion, $m \equiv n(\bmod k)$ means that $m$ and $n$ have the same remainder when divided by $k$ (referred to as ‚Äú$m$ is congruent to $n$ modulo $k$‚Äù). It is easy to see that,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
96^{2} \equiv 16(\bmod 100) . \\
96^{4} \equiv 56(\bmod 100), \\
96^{6} \equiv 96(\bmod 100), \\
\therefore 96^{6+r} \equiv\left(96^{6}\right)^{k} \cdot 96^{r}(\bmod 100) \\
\quad \equiv 96^{4+}(\bmod 100) \\
\therefore 96^{1096}=96^{6 \times 33 z+4} \equiv 96^{336}(\bmod 100) \\
\equiv 96^{6 \times 56}(\bmod 100) \equiv 96^{56}(\bmod 100) \\
\equiv 96^{6 \times 9+2}(\bmod 100) \equiv 96^{11}(\bmod 100) \\
\equiv 96^{6 \times 1+5}(\bmod 100) \equiv 96^{6}(\bmod 100) \\
\equiv 96(\bmod 100) .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
$1.1996^{1996}$ The tens digit is ( ).
$\begin{array}{llll}\text { (A) } 1 & \text { (B) } 3 & \text { (C) } 5 & \text { (D) } 9\end{array}$
